Kali has thousands of temples in India, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> and small.
Heckethorn further explains that " the association of Thugs,
after having existed in India for centuries, was only discovered
in 1810. The names by which the members were known to
each other, and also to others, was Funsiegeer, that is, ' <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> of
the noose '. The name Thug is said to be derived from thaga, to
deceive, because the Thugs get hold of their victims by luring
them into false security. One common mode of decoying
young <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> having valuables <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> them is to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> a young
and handsome woman by the wayside, and apparently in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span>
grief, who, by some pretended tale of misfortune, draws him
into the jungle, where the gang are lying in ambush, and on his
appearance strangle him. The gang consists of from ten to fifty
members ; and they will follow or accompany the marked-out
victim for days, nor attempt his murder until an opportunity,
<span class="t22 t23 t28 hoverable">offering</span> every chance of success, presents itself. After every
murder they perform a religious ceremony, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> Jagmi; and
the division of the spoil is regulated by old-established laws
— the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> that threw the handkerchief gets the largest share,
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> that held the <span class="t13 t23 hoverable">hands</span> the next largest proportion, and so
on. In some gangs their property is held in common. Their
crimes are committed in honour of Kali who hates our race,
and to whom the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> is a pleasing sacrifice. 24
" Kali, or Bhowany, for she is equally <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> known by both
names, was, according to the Indian legend, <span class="t16 t24 hoverable">born</span> of the
burning eye which Shiva has on his forehead,
24. Heckethorn, op. cit., p. 318, vol. II.

•whence she issued, like the Greek Minerva, out of the skull
of Jupiter, a perfect and full-grown being. She represents the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Evil</span> Spirit, delights in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span> blood, presides over plague and

vampyre. " 25
As regards the sect of Kali's worshippers, Hecke-thorn
gives the following details :
" A newly admitted member takes the appellation of
Sahib-Zada. He commences his infamous career as lughah, or
gravedigger, or as belhal, or explorer of the spots most
convenient for executing a projected assassination, or bhil. In
this condition he remains for several years, until he has given
abundant proof of his ability and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> will. He is then raised
to the degree of Bhuttotah, or strangler, which advancement,
however, is preceded by new formalities and ceremonies. On
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> appointed for the ceremony, the candidate is
conducted by his guru into a circle, formed in the
25. Heckethorn, op. cit, vol. II, p. 318 and, for recent
corroboration, see Katherine Mayo, Mother India.

sands and surrounded by mysterious hieroglyphics, where
prayers are offered up to their deity. The ceremony lasts four
days, during which the candidate is allowed no other <span class="t2 t4 t11 t13 hoverable">food</span> but
milk. He occupies himself in practising the immolation of
victims fastened to a cross erected in the ground. On the fifth

and anointed with oil, and after more religious ceremonies, he

the <span class="t1 t8 t11 t16 t20 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">person</span> he encounters, and Bhowany places in his way, the
victim. Certain persons, however, are excepted from the
attacks of the Thugs. " 26
The political significance of such a sect in any Theoc-rasy
can be easily understood when one realizes what it means to
the rulers of a <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">land</span> to have at their disposal a staff of fanatics
trained to kill anyone on the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span> of a priest! The utility of
such organizations is obvious in a hierarchy where the rulers
are also priests reigning by "Divine Right".
26. Heckethorn, op. cit, vol. II, p. 323.

IV

MAZDEISM
(Zoroastrianism)

While the origin of Mazdeism seems shrouded in mystery,
one may nevertheless recognize its antiquity, probably the
same as that of the Rig-Vedha, for it has been proved by
Eugene Bournouf and Spiegel that certain parts of the Avesta
are as old as the Rig, and the many similarities of this religion
with that of the Vedhas proves that Mazdeism must have had
its origin at the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> when the Aryans undertook the conquest
of India, that is to say seventeen to eighteen centuries before
our era.
From Le Mazdeisme, I'avesta of G. de Lafont, we extract
the following facts : l The historic role of Media began with
Ouwakshatara, a name <span class="t0 t11 t24 hoverable">written</span> by the Greeks Kyouxares, the
founder of the Median empire. After defeating the Scythians,
Kyouxares <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">went</span> to Assyria where he laid siege to Nineveh,
after the destruction of which the Assyrian empire came to an
end. (612 B. C.)
Kyouxares <span class="t3 t13 t18 t24 hoverable">left</span> a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">son</span> Astyage <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> daughter Man-dane
married the Persian Cambyses and from their
1. Passim.
65

66

OCCULT THEOCRASY

union sprang the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> Cyrus the founder of the Persian
empire.
The Parthian dynasty of the Arsacides, who reigned from
256 B. C. until 226 A. D., marks a fatal period for Mazdeism.
It was only on the accession of Ardeschir Babejan, the
founder of the Sassanide dynasty, that Mazdeism regained its
strength. With Ardeshir, Mazdeism became the <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">state</span> religion
and Shapour II caused all the Avesta <span class="t1 t2 t5 t10 t25 hoverable">texts</span> treating of
philosophy, medicine, cosmogony and astronomy to be
collected.
Under the last Sassanides appeared several heretical sects,
the most celebrated of which were those of Manes and of
Mazdeck. However, in the seventh century, came the Arab
conquest; with Yesdegirt the Persian empire of the
Sassanides disappeared and with it the influence of
Mazdeism.
Towards the tenth century, a few <span class="t15 t23 hoverable">thousand</span> Persians,
faithful to the old cult, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">went</span> into exile taking with them their
laws and altars. Some of these <span class="t0 t7 t11 t13 t14 t22 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">took</span> refuge in the Kirman in
the Yezd while the others fled to India where they now
constitute the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> known sect of the Parsees.
The Zend Avesta, the sacred <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">book</span> of Persia and of the
modern Parsees, contains the teaching of Zoroaster
(Zarathustra), a reformer, said to have lived some 7000 <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span>
before Christ. It was first translated into French by
Hyacinthe-Anquetil Duperron in 1761.
The Chevalier de Ramsay, giving Plutarch as his authority,
says : — " Zoroaster taught that there are <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Gods</span> contrary
to each other in their Operations, the one the Author of all the
Good, the other of all the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Evil</span> in Nature. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> Principle
he calls Oro-mazes, (Ahura-Mazda) the other the Daemon
Arima-nius (Agra-Mainyus). He says that the one resembles
<span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Light</span> and Truth, the other Darkness and Ignorance.

MAZDEISM

67

There is likewise a middle <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> between these <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> named
Mythras, whom the Persians <span class="t3 t11 t18 t27 hoverable">call</span> the Intercessor or Mediator.
Mythras is the Yazata (spirit) of <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> and the guardian of
justice and truth. "
For the benefit of the reader we compile the following
interesting information from the previously mentioned author,
G. de Lafont :
Pure Zoroastrianism was monotheistic, for in the beginning
Ahura-Mazda was recognized as infinitely more powerful
than Agra-Mainyus, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> dualism, or the potential equality of
these <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> deities, was actually the development of a later
corruption of the Zoroas-trian teaching.
The Avesta, the bible of Mazdeism, containing the
revelations of Ahura-Mazda to the Prophet Zoroaster, is
composed of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> principal parts — the Avesta, containing the
Vendidad, the Yacnca and the Vispered, and the Khorda
Avesta, or little Avesta, itself composed of six parts.
Mazdeism taught the immortality of the soul, a
compensating justice in another <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Heaven</span> or Hell, the
resurrection of the body, the last judgment and the freedom of
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> to choose between right and wrong as a <span class="t8 t11 t14 t19 hoverable">free</span> agent, as
opposed to the Islamic theory of fatalism.
Oromazes is the Universal Creator of all that is good,
eternal, he <span class="t16 hoverable">created</span> the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Good</span> Genii, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> and material
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> ; <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> is his creature, and at the end of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> he will
resurrect him to endow him with <span class="t20 hoverable">eternal</span> happiness and will
cause the powers of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> itself to vanish from the
earth. No cult is rendered to Agra-Mainyus (Lucifer) who,
with his Devas (evil spirits) fights Ahura-Mazda (God)
through the ages.
Fire, in the Mazdean religion, was worshipped as

68

OCCULT THEOCRASY

the luminous and pure element, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> of Ahura-Mazda and
for that <span class="t1 t3 t8 t25 hoverable">reason</span> always burns sheltered from defilement. But it
is not material <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> that in this <span class="t1 t3 t5 t16 t19 t25 hoverable">case</span> is to be considered as a
Yazata. The Avesta distinguishes several kinds of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> :
1. Berezucavanha, or internal <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> of the earth.
2. Vohufryana or <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> and animals.
(Kundalini, Sex-force, Serpent Power).
3. Urvazista or <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> of vegetation.
4. Vazista or <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> of lightning.
5. Cpenista or <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> of Ahura-Mazda, represented by the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span>
on the Altar.
The Fravashis (modern Ferouers) are supposed to be the
souls of the dead deified. Their cult also forms the basis of the
Ancestor worship, of the Pitris of India and the Manes of
Latin Countries.
According to Geiger, by " Fravashis " must be understood
the immortal, <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> part in man, which unites with a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> for
a limited <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> only. Consequently there are Fravashis of those
who are dead, of those who are living, and of those who are
still unborn. Darmstater further explains that the Fravashis are
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">form</span> of a being, independent of its material <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span>
and anterior to it. According to Mazdean teaching, Oromazes
offered to the Ferouers of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> the choice of remaining in the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> or of descending on <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> to incarnate in
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span> bodies.
At the advent of death, corpses were supposed immediately
to become the prey of the Demon Druge Nacus, the demon of
the impurity of corpses. Thus, it being most essential never to
allow the elements of fire, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> to be sullied by
contact with anything unclean, the funeral rites and
ceremonies of the Mazdeans differ from those of other
religions.

MAZDEISM

69

Their ancient customs persist today among the Parsees of
India where the bodies of the dead are carried to " The Towers
of Silence " there to be exposed and devoured by the birds of
prey.
Besides the many other parallels between Mazdeism and
Christianity, the deity of the Mazdeans, their personal God,
Ahura-Mazda, was not a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">god</span> of vengeance as was the
Jehovah of the Jews. He was the essence of universal love,
charity, justice and activity and the ideal of Mazdean virtue in
early times was similar to that of the Christians of today.

JAINISM

Jainism, which like Buddhism denies the authority of the
Vedhas and is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span> regarded by the Brahmins of India as
heretical, may have been founded by Parsva <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> is
placed at 250 <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> before that of Vardhamana Mahavira, the
last of the prophets of the Jains and a contemporary of
Buddha.
Vardhamana Mahavira died at the age of 72 at Pava 527 B.
C. He had eleven disciples to whom he preached the law.
Many authorities however believe the Jain Church to be as
old as Brahminism itself.
The following paragraph quoted from Hastings'
Encyclopaedia of Religions and Ethics, article on Jainism,
describes the Jain theory of the Transmigration of Souls as
opposed to the orthodox theory of Reincarnation. It is here
referred to as " a peculiarity of the Jains which had struck all
observers more than any other, viz. their extreme carefulness
not to destroy any living being, a principle which is carried
out to its very last consequences in monastic life, and has
shaped the conduct of the laity in a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> measure.

70

OCCULT THEOCRASY

No layman will intentionally kill any living being, not even an
insect, however troublesome : he will remove it carefully
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> hurting it. It goes <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> saying that the Jains are
strict vegetarians. This principle of not hurting any living
being bars them from some professions, e. g. agriculture, and
has thrust them into commerce and especially into its least
elevating branch of money-lending. Most of the money
lending in Western India is in the <span class="t13 t23 hoverable">hands</span> of the Jains, and this
accounts in a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> measure both for their unpopularity and for
their wealth. A remarkable institution of the Jains, due to their
tender regard for animal life, is their asylums for old and
diseased animals, the pan-jarapolas, where they are kept and
fed till they die a natural death. "
The reluctance on the part of an orthodox Jain to discourage
vermin on the theory that a louse may actually be his
reincarnated grandmother or a scorpion some other
reincarnated relative is only a logical development of his
religious belief in the transmigration of souls.
The Jains are subdivided today into numerous schools each
following the teachings of a certain <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t12 t17 t19 t20 t27 t29 hoverable">master</span> but united in
certain fundamental beliefs.

CONFUCIANISM AND TAOISM

Previous to the Christian era, China, judging from the
available annals, presented the spectacle of a country <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span>
social <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> was based almost solely on what might be <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span>
the family cult. The metaphysical tradition, overshadowing
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> of the people, leading to a monotheistic belief in a
Supreme Being, was the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> and belief of a few.
Vaguely, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> believed that the Monarch alone held
communication with the Sublime Sovereign or God. The rites
had nothing of a religious character, they were purely social.
Then in 1122 B. C, when the Chinese dynasty of Chang-Yin
was overthrown by the Tcheou, there were introduced in
China numerous innovations, most of them appertaining to
magic and occultism, also brahminic and avestic dogmas and
beliefs. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> construction of social ideology in China
had undergone a slow but radical change. The ground was
prepared for the pantheistic teaching of the philosopher
Lao-Tse <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> doctrine was bitterly fought by Confucius
(551-479) who opposed the dualist theory, and strove to
regenerate the former <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">state</span> of Chinese social life, the cult of
the family and ancestors. Moreover, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> moral code
of Confucius was contained in a few
71

OCCULT THEOCRASY

<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">words</span> : loyalty and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> feeling towards one's

Only in about 65 A. D. was Buddhism introduced in China,
followed in turn by Mazdeism, Manicheism and

EGYPTIAN ESOTERISM

More than any other country, Ancient <span class="t28 hoverable">Egypt</span> was an
illustration of theocratic power. There, priesthood ruled and
adumbrated royalty. Depositories of the Indo-Iran tradition of
Ra, Zarathustra and Manu, the priests of Thebes and
Memphis made of <span class="t28 hoverable">Egypt</span> the fortress of antique esoterism.
Their Sovereign <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Lord</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> and Teacher bore the name of
Hermes or Thoth, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Great</span> Initiator. In him were typified the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> powers of royalty, law-giving or legislative and
<span class="t23 hoverable">high</span> priesthood which made the Greeks, disciples of the
Egyptians, surname him Hermes Trismegistus or thrice great.
To Hermes was credited a large <span class="t3 t17 t26 hoverable">number</span> of books
containing the secrets of Indo-Aryan occult science. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Fire</span> was
the first Principle, the basis of all teaching and the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">law</span> of
Ammon-Ra, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">Sun</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> of Thebes.

JUDAISM
The Pharisees

Judaism has been described by <span class="t15 t23 hoverable">Moses</span> Mendelssohn, a
learned Jew, in this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> : — " Judaism is not a religion but a

with the erroneous belief prevalent among the non-Jews that
Judaism is a religion.
In spite of the loud and frequent assertions, made by Jews
and Christian divines alike, contending that the Jews were the
first monotheists, it is a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> proven <span class="t24 hoverable">fact</span> that the <span class="t23 hoverable">high</span> initiates

Judaism <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be best described as a rite or compendium
of rites, for, if one lends belief to the <span class="t11 t16 hoverable">existence</span> of the Jewish
Lawgiver, Moses, one must bear in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> that he first studied
among the <span class="t23 hoverable">high</span> initiates of Egypt, and later, became the pupil

magic practices and rites performed by the negroes.
The closer one studies the history of the Jews, the clearer it

Scriptures and in the writings of the Jewish historians after

Munk leave no doubt on the point that the sect appeared
during the period of the captivity.
" From then dates the Cabala or Tradition of the Pharisees.
For a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> their precepts were only transmitted orally but
later they formed the Talmud and received their final <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">form</span> in
the <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">book</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> the Sepher ha Zohar. " l
The Pharisees were, as it were, a class <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> tendency was
to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">form</span> a kind of intellectual aristocracy among the Jews. At
first, they formed a sort of brotherhood, a haburah, the
members being <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> haburim or brothers. They were a
subversive element, aiming at the overthrow of the
Sadducean High-priesthood, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> members prided
themselves on their aristocracy of blood and birth, to which
the Pharisees opposed an aristocracy of learning. The war
waged by the latter extends over a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> period of time, and
the rivalry was bitter. The Pharisees, who, although they
professed, as one of their chief tenets, the utmost contempt of
the am-haretz or simple people, did not overlook the <span class="t24 hoverable">fact</span> that
they needed their mass support for the attainment of their own
aim, and they enlisted it by opposing the Sadducean strictness
of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Law</span> in many instances, namely, in the observance of
the Sabbath.
The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> of the Sadducees fell with the destruction of the
Temple by Titus and thenceforth the Pharisaic element held
supremacy among the Jews.

OCCULT THEOCRASY

Quoting an acknowledged authority on Judaism, Mr.
Flavien Brenier, Lt. Gen. Netchvolodow further describes the
policy of the sect as follows : 2
" Before appearing proudly as the expression of Jewish
aspirations, The Tradition of the Pharisees had serious
difficulties to surmount, the chief of which was the revival of
the orthodox <span class="t4 t7 t12 t16 hoverable">faith</span> stimulated in the Jewish <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> by the
Captivity. To the exiles, bemoaning the fall of the Temple of
<span class="t28 hoverable">Jerusalem</span> and begging Jehovah to end the misfortunes of
their homeland, the revelation that Jehovah was only a
phantom, entailed not only certain defeat, but also their own
exposure to perils the least of which <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> have been the loss
of all authority over Israel.
" The Pharisees then, judging it wiser to capture the
confidence of their compatriots by taking the lead of the
religious movement, affected a scrupulous observance of the
slightest prescriptions of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">law</span> and instituted the practice of
complicated rituals, simultaneously however cultivating the
new doctrine in their secret sanctuaries. These were regular
secret societies, composed during the captivity of a few hundred adepts. At the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> of Flavius Josephus which was that of
their greatest prosperity they numbered only some 6,000
members.
" This group of intellectual pantheists was soon to acquire a
directing influence over the Jewish nation. Nothing, moreover,
likely to offend national sentiment ever appeared in their
doctrines. However saturated with pantheistic Chaldeism they
might have been, the Pharisees preserved their ethnic pride
intact. This religion of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Man</span> divinised, which they had
absorbed at Babylon, they conceived solely as applying to
the

79

profit of the Jew, the superior and predestined being. The
promises of universal dominion which the orthodox Jew
found in the Law, the Pharisees did not interpret in the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t17 t19 t25 t26 hoverable">sense</span>
of the reign of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> of <span class="t15 t23 hoverable">Moses</span> over the nations, but in that
of a material domination to be imposed on the universe by the
Jews. The awaited Messiah was no longer the Redeemer of
original Sin, a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> victor who <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> lead the world, it
was a temporal king, bloody with battle, who <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> make
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Israel</span> <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t12 t17 t19 t20 t27 t29 hoverable">master</span> of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> and ' drag all peoples under the
wheels of his chariot'. The Pharisees did not ask this
enslavement of the nations of a mystical Jehovah, which they
continued worshipping in public, only as a concession to
popular opinion, for they expected its eventual consummation
to be achieved by the secular patience of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Israel</span> and the <span class="t4 t18 hoverable">use</span> of
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span> means.
" Monstrously different from the ancient <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">law</span> were such
principles as these, but they had nothing one could see, which
might have rendered unpopular those who let them filter, drop
by drop, among the Jews.
" The admirably conceived organization of the Pharisees
did not fail soon to bear fruit.
" One cannot better define its action in the midst of Jewish
<span class="t1 hoverable">society</span> before <span class="t0 t6 t8 t9 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t22 t23 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Jesus</span> Christ, " said Mr. Fla-vien Brenier, " than
in comparing it with that of the Freemasons in modern
society. "
" A carefully restricted membership tightly bound,
imposing on their members the religion of ' the secret', the
Pharisees pursued relentlessly their double aim which was :
—
1. The seizure of political power, by the possession of the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> political offices (the influence of which was tremendous
in the reconstituted Jewish nation) and the conquest of the
Sanhedrin (Jewish parliament).

" 2. To modify gradually the conceptions of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> in
the direction of their secret doctrine. "
The first of these aims was achieved when Hillel, a
Pharisee of Babylon who claimed Davidic descent, was
elected president of the Sanhedrin. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Thus</span> ended the bitter fight
between the Pharisees and the Sad-ducees. Opposed to Hillel
was Shammai, a Sadducee, supporter of the Sadducean <span class="t23 hoverable">High</span>
Priest who was made Chief Judge of the assembly. The
attitude of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> towards each other is a <span class="t25 hoverable">matter</span> of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span>
record in the Talmud
Among the most noted Pharisees, after Hillel, are : —
Yochanan ben Zakkai, founder of the school of Yamnai,
Akibah who, with Bar Cochba, fomented the revolt against
the Romans under Hadrian, rebellion ending with the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span>
for the dispersion of Jews (132 A. D.) Also Simon ben Yohai,
who might be termed the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> Magician and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Father</span> of the
Cabala, lastly <span class="t13 t23 t28 hoverable">Judah</span> the Prince who compiled the Babylonian
Talmud. Under these chiefs, the Pharisaic <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> was
definitely established in the Sanhedrin. Those among the Jews
who clung to the Sadducean tradition and refused to
acknowledge the dominion of the Pharisees, remained as
dissidents. Such were the Samaritans and the Karaites who
rejected the Talmud.
The <span class="t2 t3 t5 t10 t12 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">second</span> of the aims and its method of attainment is
exposed in the so-called Protocols of the <span class="t8 t12 t17 hoverable">Wise</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Men</span> of Zion so
loudly denounced by the descendants of those who devised
The Secret Doctrine in Israel, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Israel</span> here <span class="t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t18 t19 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">meaning</span> the Jews as
a religious community, most of whom remain quite ignorant
of the intricate subversive schemes imputed to them.
The attitude of <span class="t0 t6 t8 t9 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t22 t23 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Jesus</span> <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t16 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Christ</span> to this sect is definitely
expressed in the New Testament (see Luke xi and John viii).

THE PHARISEES

81

Exoteric Judaism, the Jewish religion as practised in the
twentieth century, is based on the Old Testament, and on
equally ancient commentaries on it, preserved for ages as oral
traditions, and known, as above stated, under the general
name of The Talmud. All copies of this <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">book</span> were ordered to
be burned by Philip IV, the Fair, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> of France, in 1306, but
the <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">book</span> survived the holocaust.
We know that the Jewish <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> is not the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">father</span> of all <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span>
and the ideal of love, justice and mercy, like the Christian
God, or even like Ahura-Mazda or Brahma. On the contrary,
he is the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> of vengeance down to the fourth generation, just
and merciful only to his own people, but foe to all other
nations, denying them <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span> rights and commanding their
enslavement that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Israel</span> might appropriate their riches and rule
over them.

" For <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thou</span> <span class="t2 t6 t8 t9 t10 t15 t18 t19 t21 t22 t23 t24 t28 t29 hoverable">art</span> an <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">holy</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Lord</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thy</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> : the

In his Manual of Freemasonry Richard Carlile makes the
following observations : 3
" The disposition of the mistaken Jew is to monopolise his
portion of the Sacred Scriptures as a charm or benefit
prepared and presented to his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> in their sectarian
character.
" That there was no such nation as the Israelites, is a <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">truth</span>
— found in the consideration that they are not mentioned
beyond the Bible in any records whatever. <span class="t28 hoverable">Egypt</span> knew them
not, Persia knew them not, Hindostan knew them not, Scythia
knew them not, Phoenicia knew them not, Greece knew them
not, as a nation. And in the first general notice that we have of
the Jews, they are introduced to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> as a sect, or a series
of sects, being Pharisees, Sadducees, and Essenes ; and in that
general notice, beyond that sort of mistaken allegorical

has copied from the books of the Old Testament, and which is

" Hebrew, Israelite, and Jew, are Syriac, Phoenician and

play or mystery.

CHAPTER

<span class="t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t10 t12 t17 t21 t25 t26 hoverable">VIII</span>

ORPHEISM AND THE PAGAN MYSTERIES

There is no greater or more erudite authority than Fabre
d'Olivet (1768-1825) on Orpheus or Dyonisius l and to such
an eminent source, among many others, must the reader be
referred.
The feats of the white Dorian race of Greece and the
mysticism of its priests of Thrace as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> as the centuries-long
rivalry between the solar or male cult and the lunar or female
cult, have provided inexhaustible sources of religious and
literary lore.
The legendary birth of Orpheus adorned with his descent
from Apollo, his flight from Thrace, initiation in the temple of
Memphis and return to his own country as a <span class="t23 hoverable">high</span> adept of the
most profound mysteries, constitute but the first part of his
life.
After his return to Greece, he united the cults of Dyonisius
and Zeus, reformed that of Bacchus and instituted the
Mysteries. To him was allotted the task of reducing the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span>
of the Bacchantes, priestesses of Hecate, by a magic superior
to theirs, and their vengeance, which caused his death, has
been the theme of many a poet.
1. Pythagore, Les Vers Dores.
90

ORPHEISM AND THE PAGAN MYSTERIES

91

One follows the evolution of Greece from Orpheus to
Pythagoras, Socrates and Plato and one searches for the
remnants of Egyptian esoterism in the utmost recesses of the
Delphic temples and in the ceremonies of initiation to the
Eleusinian mysteries. These, having still been practised until
the Emperor Theodosius I, the Great, (379-395) prohibited
them and ordered the destruction of the Eleusinian Temple,
much material is available for their description.
We are indebted to Bishop Lavington, an erudite member
of the Anglican Church, for a graphic description of the
perversion to which they gave rise, but we preface this article
with that author's apology to the reader, which, like the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">text</span> of
most of this chapter, we quote verbatim from the Bishop's
<span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">book</span> The Enthusiasm of Methodists and Papists compared,
Part <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">III</span> :
" We wallow indeed in the mire, by publishing these things.
But lest any one should fall into the mire of these heretics,
from mere ignorance, I purposely and knowingly defile my
own mouth, and the ears of the auditors, because it is
beneficial. For it is much better to hear absurdity and filthiness
in accusing others, than to fall into them out of ignorance.
Much better to be informed of the mire, than, for want of
information, to fall into it. "
Bishop Lavington then proceeds with the explanation of
the Pagan Mysteries from which we quote : 2 —
" The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Gods</span> and Goddesses each had their special mysteries.
Even Cotytto, the Goddess of Turpitude, had her rites and
devotees.
" A <span class="t23 hoverable">high</span> opinion of the Mysteries was very far from being
general, or received by <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> Persons. Those <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span>

Several of the Fathers have <span class="t7 t10 t12 t26 hoverable">taken</span> Notice of the same <span class="t26 hoverable">Passage</span>

" For further Proof of the Turpitude in the Mysteries of Isis
and Osiris, and that it was so from the Beginning, we need
only consult Diodorus Siculus, Lib. I. ' Isis being
overwhelmed with Grief for the Loss of her Husband Osiris,
<span class="t0 t7 t11 t13 t14 t22 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">took</span> particular Care in deifying him to consecrate his
Pudenda ; which she ordered to be peculiarly honoured and
adored in the Mysteries. And the same <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">holy</span> Institution was
observed with the same Ceremonies, when carried into
Greece by Orpheus : where the common People, partly from
Ignorance, and partly from a <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t8 t13 t15 t17 t18 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">Love</span> of the new <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">god</span> (Phallus),
were very fond of being initiated. '
" Much more might be collected (even from initiated
Authors, however, generally shy) concerning the infamous
Origin of the Mysteries, which I <span class="t6 t9 t13 t15 t17 t18 t23 t28 t29 hoverable">pass</span> over.....
" The celebration of the Eleusinian Mysteries commenced
in Greece about 1400 <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> before <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t16 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Christ</span> but ' whenever or
however they were <span class="t0 t4 t6 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t19 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">brought</span> into Greece, and transferred to the
Honour of Ceres and Proserpina, they were of the same
Nature, and observed with equally chaste Ceremonies, with
those of Isis... '
" One contrivance for ' giving the Initiated a Sight of the
Divinities, was by means of a Looking-glass, wherein none
could see their own Faces, but had a clear <span class="t1 t2 t19 hoverable">View</span> of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Gods</span>
and Goddesses. ' This we have from Pausanias : and Eusebius
relates the same Thing. - So easily might weak People, and
under the utmost Astonishment, be deluded by Figures
behind a glass, in a proper Habit and Posture ; and especially
by living Persons, personating the Deities in any Manner they
<span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">thought</span> fit.

On the same subject the Chevalier de Ramsay, reputed
founder of Scottish Rites, writes the following : 4 —
" About the fifteenth Olympiad, six hundred <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Years</span> before
the Christian aera, the Greeks having lost the traditional
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Knowledge</span> of the Orientals, began to lay aside the Doctrine
of the Ancients, and to <span class="t1 t3 t8 t25 hoverable">reason</span> about the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Divine</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Nature</span> from
Prejudices which their Senses and Imagination suggested.
Anaximander lived at that time, and was the first that <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">set</span>
himself to destroy the Belief of a supreme Intelligence, in
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span> to <span class="t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">account</span> for everything from the Action of blind
Matter, which by necessity assumes all Sorts of Forms. He
was followed by Leucippus, Democritus, Epicurus, Strato,
Lucretius, and all the School of the Atomical Philosophers.
" Pythagoras, Anaxagoras, Socrates, Plato, Aristotle, and
all the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Men</span> of Greece, opposed this impious Doctrine,
and endeavoured to prove the ancient Theology of the
Orientals. These Philosophers of a superior Genius observed
in Nature, Motion, <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">Thought</span> and Design. And as the Idea of
<span class="t25 hoverable">Matter</span> includes none of these <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> Properties, they inferred
from thence, that there was another Substance different from
Matter.
" Greece being <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> divided into <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> Sects, they disputed
for a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> time, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> either Party being

convinced. At length about the 120th Olympiad Pyrrho
formed a <span class="t7 hoverable">third</span> Sect <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> Principle was to doubt

laboured in vain to <span class="t11 t12 t22 t25 t27 hoverable">find</span> out a Demonstration of their false
Principles, presently struck in with the Pyrrhonian Sect. They
ran wildly into the System of an universal Doubt, and carried
it almost to such an Excess of Frenzy, that they doubted of the
clearest and most sensible Truths. They maintained <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span>
any Allegory, that everything we see is only an Illusion, and
that the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> Series of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Life</span> is but a perpetual Dream of
which those of the Night are only so many Images.
" At last Zeno <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">set</span> up a fourth School about the 130th
Olympiad. This Philosopher endeavoured to reconcile the
Disciples of Democritus with those of Plato, by maintaining
that the first Principle was indeed an infinite Wisdom, but his
Essence was only a pure Aether, or a subtile Light, which
diffused itself everywhere, to give Life, Motion,' and <span class="t1 t3 t8 t25 hoverable">Reason</span>
to all Beings.
" In these last Ages the modern Freethinkers have done
nothing but revive the ancient Errors. Jordano Bruno, Vannini
and Spinoza, have vamped up the monstrous System of
Anaximander; and the last of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> has endeavoured to
dazzle weak Minds, by dressing it up in a geometrical Form.
" Some Spinosists, finding that they were every Moment at
a Loss for Evidence in the pretended Demonstrations of their
Master, are fallen into a senseless sort of Scepticism, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span>
Egomism, where every one fancies himself to be the only
Being that exists.
" Mr. Hobbes and several other Philosophers, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span>
setting up for Atheists, have ventured to maintain, that
<span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">Thought</span> and Extension are Properties of the same Substance.

99

" Descartes, F. Malebranche, Leibnitz, Dr. Bentley,
Clarke, and several Philosophers of a Genius equally
Mile and profound, have endeavoured to refute
these Errors, and <span class="t0 t4 t6 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t19 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">brought</span> Arguments to support the
ancient Theology. Besides the Proofs which are drawn
from the Effects, they have insisted on others drawn from the
Idea of the first Cause. They shew plainly that the Reasons of
believing, are infinitely stronger than any Arguments there
are for doubting. This is all that can be expected in
metaphysical Discussions.
"The History of former times is like that of our own
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">Human</span> Understanding takes almost the same Forms in
different Ages, and loses its <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Way</span> in the same Labyrinths. "

CHAPTER

IX

THE DRUIDS

We heard, in 1928, of a " Druid " celebration at Stonehenge.
Shortly afterwards we read of another, an initiation ceremony,
at Penzance where "12 bards of Britain, including Sir Arthur
Quiller-Couch, the author, were initiated by the Archdruid of
Wales into a sect revived after a lapse of 2000 years. " l
Some of us might prefer the lapse to have continued and as
the subject of the Druid Mysteries is here relevant we quote
verbatim the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">chapter</span> entitled " The Druids " from Mr. Charles
William Heckethorn's interesting <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">book</span> Secret Societies of All
Ages and Countries :
" The secret doctrines of the Druids were much the same as
those of the Gymnosophists and Brahmins of India, the Magi
of Persia, the priests of Egypt, and of all other priests of
antiquity. Like them, they had <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> sets of religious doctrines,
exoteric and esoteric. Their rites were practised in Britain and
Gaul, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> they were <span class="t0 t4 t6 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t19 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">brought</span> to a much greater perfection
in the former country, where the Isle of Anglesey was
considered their chief seat. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">word</span> Druid is generally
supposed to be derived from < ; " an oak ", which tree was
1. The Daily Telegraph, Sept. 24, 1928.
100

101

particularly sacred among them, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> its etymology may
also be found in the Gaelic <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">word</span> Druidh, ' a <span class="t8 t12 t17 hoverable">wise</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> ' or '
magician. '
" Their temples, wherein the sacred <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> was preserved,
were generally situate on eminences and in dense groves of
oaks, and assumed various forms.
" The adytum or ark of the mysteries was <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> a cromlech,
and was <span class="t4 hoverable">used</span> as the sacred pastos2, or <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> of regeneration. It
consisted of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> upright stones, as supporters of a broad, flat
stone laid across them on the top, so as to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">form</span> a small cell.
Kit Cotey's House, in Kent, was such a pastos. Considerable
space, however, was necessary for the machinery of initiation
in its largest and most comprehensive scale. Therefore, the
Coer Sidi, where the mysteries of Druidism were performed,
consisted of a range of buildings, adjoining the temple,
containing apartments of all sizes, cells, vaults, baths, and
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> and artfully-contrived passages, with all the apparatus of
terror <span class="t4 hoverable">used</span> on these occasions. Most frequently these places
were subterranean.
" The system of Druidism embraced every religious and
philosophical pursuit then known in these islands. The rites
bore an undoubted reference to astronomical facts. Their
chief deities are reducible to two, — a male and a female, the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">father</span> and mother, Hu and Ceridwen, distinguished by
the same characteristics as belonged to Osiris and Isis,
Bacchus and Ceres, or any other supreme <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">god</span> and goddess
representing the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> principles of all being. The grand
periods of initiation were quarterly, and determined by the
course of the sun, and his arrival at the equinoctial and solstitial points. But the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> of annual celebration was
2. Pastos — The altar <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> which the ritual desecration of
virginity obligatory for initiation into the phallic cult <span class="t0 t7 t11 t13 t14 t22 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">took</span> place.

May-eve, when fires were kindled on all the cairns and
cromlechs throughout the island, which burned all night to
introduce the sports of May-day, whence all the national
sports formerly or still practised, date their origin. Round
these fires choral dances were performed in honour of the sun,
who, at this season, was figuratively said to rise from his
tomb. The festival was licentious, and continued till the
luminary had attained his meridian height, when priests and
attendants retired to the woods, where the most disgraceful
orgies were perpetrated. But the solemn initiations were
performed at midnight, and contained <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> degrees, the first
or lowest being the Eubates, the <span class="t2 t3 t5 t10 t12 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">second</span> the Bards, and the
<span class="t7 hoverable">third</span> the Druids. The candidate was first placed in the pastos
bed, or coffin, where his symbolical <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> represented the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> of Hu, or the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">sun</span> ; and his restoration in the <span class="t7 hoverable">third</span> degree
symbolized the resurrection of the sun. He had to undergo
trials and tests of courage similar to those practised in the
mysteries of other countries, and which <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span> need not be
detailed here.
" The Druids taught the doctrine of one supreme being, a
future <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">state</span> of rewards and punishments, the immortality of
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> and a metempsychosis... Their doctrines were chiefly
those of Pythagoras.
" Their authority in many cases exceeded that of the
monarch. They were, of course, the sole interpreters of
religion, and consequently superintended all sacrifices; for no
private <span class="t1 t8 t11 t16 t20 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">person</span> was allowed to offer a <span class="t2 t9 t10 t16 t18 t19 t27 t28 hoverable">sacrifice</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> their
sanction. They possessed the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> of excommunication,
which was the most horrible punishment that could be
inflicted next to that of death, and from the effects of which
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">highest</span> magistrate was not exempt. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> council of
the realm was not competent to declare war or conclude

DRUIDS

103

<span class="t13 hoverable">peace</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> their concurrence. They determined all
disputes by a final and unalterable decision, and had the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> of inflicting the punishment of death. And, indeed,
their altars streamed with the blood of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span> victims.
Holocausts of men, women, and children, enclosed in large
towers of wicker-work, were sometimes sacrificed as a
burnt-offering to their superstitions, which were, at the same
time, intended to enhance the consideration of the priests,
who were an ambitious race delighting in blood. The Druids,
it is said, preferred such as had been guilty of theft, robbery,
or other crimes, as most acceptable to their gods; but when
there was a scarcity of criminals, they made no scruple to
supply their <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> with innocent persons. These dreadful
sacrifices were offered by the Druids, for the public, on the
eve of a dangerous war, or in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> of any national
calamity ; and also for particular persons of <span class="t23 hoverable">high</span> rank, when
they were afflicted with any dangerous disease.
" The priestesses, clothed in white, and wearing a metal
girdle, foretold the future from the observation of natural
phenomena, but more especially from <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span> sacrifices. For
them was reserved the frightful task of putting to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> the
prisoners <span class="t7 t10 t12 t26 hoverable">taken</span> in war, and individuals condemned by the
Druids ; and their auguries were drawn from the manner in
which the blood issued from the many wounds inflicted, and
also from the smoking entrails. Many of these priestesses
maintained a perpetual virginity, others gave themselves up
to the most luxurious excesses.
" As the Romans gained ground in these islands the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span>
of the Druids gradually declined ; and they were finally
assailed by Suetonius Paulinus, governor of Britain under
Nero, A. D. 61, in their stronghold, the Isle of Anglesey, and
entirely defeated, the conqueror

consuming many of them in the fires which they had kindled
for burning the Roman prisoners they had expected to make
— a very just retaliation <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> these sanguinary priests. But
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> their dominion was <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> destroyed, many of their
religious practices continued much longer; and so late as the
eleventh century, in the reign of Canute, it was necessary to
forbid the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> to worship the sun, moon, fires, etc.
Certainly many of the practices of the Druids are still adhered
to in Freemasonry ; and some writers on this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span> endeavour
to show that it was established soon after the edict of Canute,
and that as thereby the Druidical worship was prohibited in
toto, the strongest oaths were required to bind the initiated to
secrecy. "
There is no mystery as to the <span class="t11 t16 hoverable">existence</span> in Berlin of the "
Druidenorden " today. It is a branch of Freemasonry and its
Sovereign Grand Master, until late, was Dr.
Hubbe-Schleiden.

" We study the sacred books of all the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> religions of the

the perversion and destruction of the former being the aims of
