Socinius which had been spread among them by his. nephew
Faustus Socinius who had found refuge in Moravia when
persecuted by the Church. Their link with Rosicrucianism had
already been established in the <span class="t1 t8 t11 t16 t20 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">person</span> of the pietist, Julius
Sperber, who was also one of their leaders. When Kominsky
was persecuted, he first <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">went</span> to London in 1641 and, early the
next year, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">went</span> to Sweden where he was granted refuge and
help by the powerful Swedish Minister, Count Axel
Oxenstiern, himself a Rosicrucian adept and protector of
another initiate, Ludwig van Geer from Holland.
The combination of the pursuit of alchemy and
her-meticism with political aims was frequently evidenced
even before the official appearance of Rosicrucianism. The
influence of adepts on the destinies of nations was immense.
To Queen Elizabeth, the advice of John Dee, her alchemist,
was always considered in matters affecting national policy,
and to Dee, his crystal gazer, Edward Kelly, was
indispensable as a medium. 7
Ludwig van Geer, (one of the Seven present at
Magdebourg) had settled in Sweden and had won over the
chancellor, Count Axel Oxenstiern, then the real regent, in
<span class="t1 t2 t19 hoverable">view</span> of the minority of Queen Christina. A <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> industrialist
of Dutch birth, with a colossal fortune made in the
manufacture of cannon, he had become a Baron, and as owner
of 20 ships of the Swedish fleet, he was an indispensable
man.
Another striking Rosicrucian figure was Thomas Vaughan,
(Eugenius Philaletes) not to be confused with his pupil,
George Starkey, known as Irenius Philaletes.
It is said that it was Thomas Vaughan who, inspired
7. Charlotte Fell Smith, op. cit., p. 182.

THE

ROSICRUCIANS

155

by the writings of Nick Stone, conceived the idea of
subverting to the ambition of the sect to which he belonged,
the guild of the Freemasons which, owing to its universal
character, lent itself better than any other to the realization of
his project.
Nick Stone was one of the Seven of the Convention of
Magdebourg. As an architect, belonging to the guild of the
Freemasons, he had helped Inigo Jones, the grand-master of
the English Lodges which, at this period, were nonsectarian.
On the other hand, as a Rosicrucian he had grasped, in the
Luciferian sense, the idea given by Faustus Socinius, and he
had composed, for the nine grades of the fraternity, rituals
which the chiefs declared remarkable. His ritual of the eighth
degree (Magister Templi) was really Satanic.
Thomas Vaughan, struck by these manuscripts wondered
<span class="t10 t12 t16 t20 t21 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">whether</span> it <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be possible to extend the teaching of the
Rose Croix to all " accepted masons ", who were then
admitted to the lodges in an honorary capacity ; the
Freemasons received in their guild, under the name of "
accepted masons ", peers and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> of letters or professional
men, as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> as rich bourgeois, who enhanced the brilliancy
of their meetings and patronized their entertainments. These
honorary members were their protectors and benefactors. 8
Vaughan believed that this element, gifted with certain
intellectual qualities, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> lend itself better to the
propagation of the principles of occult Socinian-ism than the
workers of the Fellow Craft, and, having made up his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span>
that this was the solution of the problem, he hastened to put it
into practice.
8. This is still customary. Many of the English Guilds of

OCCULT THEOCRASY

Some brothers of the Rose Croix were already mingling
with the Freemasons. Among the members of the Warrington
Lodge were Richard Penkett, James Collier, Richard Sankey,
Henry Littler, John Ellam and Hugh Brewer and in London,
the Whartons and their friends had slipped into a lodge as "
accepted masons ".
Thomas Vaughan encouraged them to spread the
principles of Socinius. Finally, at a meeting on the 14th May
1643, he announced that their desultory efforts at restrained
proselytizing should be supplanted by a definite programme
of entering the guild lodges with the <span class="t2 hoverable">object</span> of using them as
instruments to an end.
The <span class="t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">account</span> of this meeting of the 14th May 1643, is given

adventurous adept that Vaughan must always remain one of
the most mysterious characters of Rosicrucianism.

The year 1644 ended with the destruction of the Royal
power, and Feb. 9, 1649, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> on which the <span class="t7 t11 t15 t22 hoverable">head</span> of

<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> had in <span class="t24 hoverable">fact</span> been wrecked when the troops of

<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">take</span> refuge in France, when the Prince Palatine, Robert, had

The connection of the Cromwell family with that of the

In 1767, a document was discovered which revealed the

The document said : — "At last the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> mine of the

which ignorant men, recruited and duped, could act like
puppets animated by unseen <span class="t13 t23 hoverable">hands</span> pulling unseen strings.
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Thus</span> it came about that all blows dealt to Christianity and
States were prepared by the secret Societies-acting behind the
veil of Masonry.

CHAPTER

XXIII

CATHARES, ALBIGENSES, WALDENSES

Manicheism, with its hierarchy and missionary system, had
<span class="t7 t10 t12 t26 hoverable">taken</span> root in Europe and, with its chief seat in Bulgaria, had
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> found its <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> into Northern Italy and the southern part of
France.
Unquestionably Manicheans in their beliefs and teachings,
the Cathares (purifiers or pure) held the unadulterated
tradition of Manes. Their hierarchy was that established by
their founder. In the 12th century, their supreme chief was in
Bulgaria having under him, bishops, priests, deacons and
simple Perfects. These composed the class of Perfects who
were distinguished from the <span class="t2 t3 t5 t10 t12 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">second</span> degree of Believers.
As to the Albigenses, their name derived from Albi, a town
of Languedoc, covered not one but many sects issued from
Manicheism and Arianism, and counted also many Jews or
judaised Christians. Under this appellation of Albigenses,
historians, <span class="t10 t12 t16 t20 t21 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">whether</span> political or religious, have almost
unanimously included the Cathares.
A revolt against the then existing Church <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> of the 12th
century is only too comprehensible, when one recollects the
excesses of which popes, bishops and almost all dignitaries
of the Church were guilty. The
163

164

OCCULT THEOCRASY

pioneers of the rebellion had been Peter of Bruys (died 1126)
and the monk Henri (died 1148).
They had openly attacked the vices of the clergy and fallen
victims, the first to his own fanaticism (he was killed by the
mob <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> anger he had aroused by pulling down a wooden
cross to be <span class="t4 hoverable">used</span> as burning wood for the purpose of cooking
meat on a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Good</span> Friday); the <span class="t2 t3 t5 t10 t12 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">second</span> was imprisoned by a
bishop against <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> vices he had raised his voice. Both had
attacked the beliefs and practices of the Church ; like the
Baptists of today they rejected the practice of baptism for
children, and denied the dogmas of transubstantiation and
redemption through Christ.
They gained many adherents and <span class="t3 t13 t18 t24 hoverable">left</span> numerous disciples
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> Manichean opposition to the Church was identical
with that of the Cathares. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Upon</span> such grounds fell the
preaching of Peter Waldo who, although he repudiated the
dualist doctrine of the Manicheans, formed a serious
opposition to the Church. He <span class="t16 hoverable">created</span> the sect of the
Waldenses divided in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> degrees, Perfect and Believers. The
former made a vow of Poverty and as such <span class="t0 t7 t11 t13 t14 t22 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">took</span> the names of
Poor Brethren, the latter formed the Outer or <span class="t7 hoverable">Third</span> Order.
From the South of France and Northern Italy, persecution
drove the Waldenses to the Central and Northern provinces of
France, thence to England, then from Lombardy into
Germany and Bohemia. John Wickliffe (1324-1384) in
England and John Huss (1369-1415) in Bohemia, were their
foremost representatives and in the latter country they formed
the Bohemian Brethren who later also <span class="t0 t7 t11 t13 t14 t22 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">took</span> the name of
Moravian Brethren or Religious Masons.

CHAPTER

XXIV

THE MORAVIANS

OR THE MORAVIAN BROTHERS OF THE <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">ORDER</span> OF RELIGIOUS
FREEMASONS, OR <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">ORDER</span> OF THE MUSTARD-SEED, OR THE
CHURCH UNITAS FRATRUM, OR THE HERRENHUTER.

Margrave Albert expelled the Jews from the town of Iglau,
in Moravia, on the ground that they had been in league with
the Taborites, the subversive element among the Hussites.
The Taborites were Bohemians.
The Moravian Brothers or Unitas Fratrum, a Gnostic sect,
were founded in 1457 at Kunewald, near Seftenberg, by
Gregory ; the nephew of the Calixtine leader Rokyzana. They
were an offshoot of the Bohemian Brethren said to represent
the religious kernel of the Hussite movement.
At the Synod of Lhota near Reichenau, in 1467, they
constituted themselves into a Church separate from the
Calixtine or National church of Bohemia.
The constitution of the <span class="t1 hoverable">society</span> was revised at a <span class="t2 t3 t5 t10 t12 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">second</span>
Synod held at Lhota under the direction of Luke of Prague,
who may be regarded as their <span class="t2 t3 t5 t10 t12 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">second</span> founder. This
reorganization enabled the <span class="t1 hoverable">society</span> to grow rapidly. In the
early <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> of the 16th cent, the
165

166

OCCULT

THEOCRASY

Unitas included nearly 400 congregations in Bohemia and
Moravia, with 150,000 members, and, including Poland,
embraced <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> provinces — Bohemia, Moravia, where the
Jews are the best educated of the inhabitants, and in a few
small towns <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">form</span> a <span class="t5 hoverable">full</span> half of the population, and Poland.
Each province had its own bishops and synods, but all were
united in one church and governed by the general synod.
The Lutheran movement in Germany awakened lively
interest among the Brethren, and some unsuccessful attempts
were made under the leadership of Agusta to unite with the
Lutheran Church (1528-1546); but when the Calvinist
reformation reached Bohemia, the Brethren found themselves
more in sympathy with it than with the Lutheran. The Jesuit
anti-reformation, instigated by Rudolf and his brothers
Matthias and Ferdinand, found the Brethren a prosperous
church, but the pitiless persecution which followed the
unsuccessful attempt at revolution crushed the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> Protestantism of Bohemia, and in 1627 the Evangelical churches
there had ceased to exist. About the same time, the Polish
branch of the Unity, in which many refugees from Bohemia
and Moravia had found a home, was absorbed in the
Reformed Church of Poland. A few families, however,
especially in Moravia, held religious services in secret,
preserved the traditions of their fathers, and, in spite of the
vigilance of their enemies, maintained some correspondence
with each other. In 1722, some of these <span class="t3 t13 t18 t24 hoverable">left</span> home and property
to seek a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> where they could worship in freedom. The first
company, led by Christian David, a mechanic, settled by
invitation from Count Zinzendorf 1 on his

Theophilus Desaguliers ; he was Spener's godchild.

estate at Bertheldsdorf near Zittau, in Saxony. They were
soon joined by others (about 300 coming <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">within</span> seven years),
and built a town which they <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> Her-renhut. The small
community at first adopted the constitution and teaching of
the old Unitas. The episcopate had been continued, and in

Renewed Moravian Church. The new settlement was not,

of the Bohemian Brethren. Zinzendorf, who had given them
an asylum, came with his wife, family, and chaplain to live
among the refugees. He was a Lutheran who had accepted
Spener's pietism, and he wished to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">form</span> a <span class="t1 hoverable">society</span> distinct

element and the adherents of the ancient Unitas Fratrum. The
emigrants at Herrenhut attended the parish church at

proselytizing. The <span class="t1 hoverable">society</span> adopted a code of rules in 1727,
and ordained twelve elders to carry on pastoral work. This
was the revival of the Unitas Fratrum as a church.
Besides congregational work, special home missions were
and are carried on in each province. In the German province
there is a peculiar home mission <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> the

CHAPTER

XXV

THE ANABAPTISTS
(Founded 1521)

The Anabaptists were founded in 1521 by Nicolas Storch,
Mark Stubner and Thomas Muncer.
Their Heresies were founded on the following Lutheran
maxim interpreted subversively : A Christian <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> is <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t12 t17 t19 t20 t27 t29 hoverable">master</span>
of everything and is subject to no one. They further claimed
that infant baptism is null, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span> adults only can be
baptized.
" If the Anabaptists ", writes Hoeninghaus, a German
Protestant writer, in La Reforme contre la Reforme, were not
all equally intolerant, they were nevertheless all equally
detested, hated, and persecuted by the Protestants much more
than by the Catholics. "
Queen Elizabeth ordered them to be excluded from
England.
Madden, in Phantasmata, describes their religion in the
following terms :
" We <span class="t11 t12 t22 t25 t27 hoverable">find</span> among them claims to intercourse with <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> and
angels — to the gift of prophecy — to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> of driving
out <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> spirits — to the right of persecuting opponents — to
visions, ecstasies, trances, convulsive seizures attributed to
supernatural influences — and all these evi171

dences of epidemic religious mania in countries which were
Protestant. " 1
At certain periods in its history, this sect wielded <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span>
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> and Madden further writes that in Westphalia " for a
length of time, the entire senate was composed of
theomaniacs. As the republic was composed alone of fools
and madmen, it is incredible to what a length they carried
their excesses in Munster : each magistrate proposed for the
rule of government the wild chimeras of his own imagination,
disguised under the imposing name of revelation. It was a sad
spectacle to hear the deliberations of a senate composed
altogether of fanatics : some being inspired in a perfectly
contrary <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> to that suggested to others : nevertheless, each
one adhering to the dictates of his inspiration, because he
believed that a special revelation had been made to him.
When such things, says Calmeil, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">take</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> in a country,
where pseudo-prophets are tolerated who disseminate terror,
and run about the streets <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> any clothing, when the
multitude <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">set</span> these <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">things</span> down as super-human phenomena ;
when the inspired of both sexes walk about <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> in public
places in the midst of their disciples and apostles, the will of
the Supreme Being is supposed to serve as a rule and direction
to all the extravagances that mortals fall into, and it is difficult
to say where will end the excesses of this religious delirium...
The Anabaptists, when they fell into the <span class="t13 t23 hoverable">hands</span> of their
enemies, allowed their fingers, tongue, nose and ears, to be
cut off, nay, even suffered themselves to be drowned by
hundreds in torrents, rather than desist or depart for a moment

ANABAPTISTS

173

In 1525, Luther headed an alliance of the Princes and
governments to repress these excesses, and they were
defeated at the Battle of Frankenhausen in that year, their
leader Thomas Muncer being seized and beheaded.
In 1536, John of Leyden proclaimed himself <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> of the
New <span class="t28 hoverable">Jerusalem</span> but his <span class="t0 t7 t21 t27 hoverable">glory</span> was of short duration. He was
<span class="t7 t10 t12 t26 hoverable">taken</span> by " the ungodly " and put to death.
The principal leaders of the sect were John Mathias, John
Bockhold, <span class="t6 t11 t13 t14 t15 t22 t23 t28 hoverable">David</span> George, William Hacket, Kotte-rus,
Kuhlmann and Dabricius.
" The principal offshoots of the Anabaptist fanaticism in
Germany, Holland, and Switzerland, were the Adamites, the
Apostolics, the Taciturn, the Perfect, the Impeccable, the
Liberated Brethren, the Sabbatarians, the Clancularians, the
Manifestarians, the Bewailers, the Rejoicers, the Indifferent,
the Sanguinarians, the Antimariens. " 3
3. Madden, op. cit., vol. II, p. 456.

CHAPTER

XXVI

GRAND LODGE OF ENGLAND
(Founded 1717)

John Valentin Andrea, the Rosicrucian, having elaborated
a plan to merge all the existing religious Societies into one
organization, published in 1614 a <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">book</span> Universal and
General Reformation of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">Whole</span> Wide World, in which he
advocated the foundation of a secret <span class="t1 hoverable">society</span> of all classes,
pledged to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> quietly for the benefit of their fellows.
To this period also belongs the legend of Christian
Rosenkreutz (see page 151).
Andrea, however, failed in his endeavours but Jan Amos
Komensky (Comenius) joined actively in his efforts and, as
early as 1628, begged leave to share in this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> of which he
presently was given sole charge.
About this time, Comenius wrote his renowned <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> on
All-wisdom, the Pansophia, which embodied his ideas on the
foundation of humanity's Utopia.
This Moravian school-master, Comenius, while doubtless
an idealist, was also interested in spiritism, prophecies,
revolution, Antichrist, the Millenium and such like whims of
a dangerous fanaticism. He collected the visions of the
Anabaptists, Kotterus and those of Dab-ricius and published
them at Amsterdam. Those visions
174

GRAND LODGE OF ENGLAND

175

promised such wonders as the extermination of the Pope, the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">House</span> of Austria, Gustavus Adolphus, Gus-tavus, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> of
Sweden, Cromwell and others and were of a most disturbing
character. 1
When Anderson undertook the task of uniting the old
traditions of practical Masonry with the more recent
development and broadened ideas of the new world-league,
he incorporated in his <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">book</span> of constitution a reproduction of
the main part of the plans and ideas of Comenius. Their <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span>
<span class="t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t18 t19 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">meaning</span> was faithfully adhered to, and important and
decisive passages were adopted almost literally.
The transformation of the Lodge was actually carried out
in 1663 when, in the General Assembly of Masons, the
masters of operative masonry, feeling themselves supplanted
and overruled, realized that if they did not wish to forsake
their Lodge they must unite with its new masters and
subordinate themselves to their designs — Henry Jermyn,
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Lord</span> St. Albans, was elected and installed Grand Master, Sir
John Denham became his deputy and Sir Christopher Wren
and John Webb, wardens.
The English Grand Lodge, as we know it, was founded on
June 24, 1717, by Anderson, Desaguliers (an expatriated
Frenchman said to have been the <span class="t7 t11 t15 t22 hoverable">head</span> of the Rose Croix),
Calvert, James King, Elliot, Lumden Madden and George
Payne.2 It <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t29 hoverable">works</span> only the first <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> degrees, Apprentice,
Fellow-Craft and <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t12 t17 t19 t20 t27 t29 hoverable">Master</span> Mason (Blue Masonry) and
constitutes the nursery for the selection of initiates for the
<span class="t1 t5 t11 t16 hoverable">higher</span> or so <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> " spurious " masonry. Masons desirous of
rising in the

We can accept the causes given above for the destruction
of these documents with a smile!
On initiation, Masons receive an alias by which name they
are henceforth known in the Lodge.
All Masonry is founded on the usual system of sectarian
help. " Help a Mason " supplants the Christian teaching of "
Help everyone ".
Until the last few <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> this rule had not assumed a
subversive character. Lately however, it is said that " to get
anywhere in business in the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">City</span> (London) one must be a
Mason ". This has stimulated Masonic recruiting, implying as
it does a virtual business boycott against non-masons. Each
new recruit weakens the forces of those <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> free,
unhampered judgment could serve the cause of real liberty,
democracy, and humanity.
Masonry, English and Continental, has been very useful to
persons with political ambitions and minor mental and moral
capacities.

To this other authors have added that this skull is known as

Council of the Globe.

The following address, n issued from Paris by Giuseppe
Mazzini12 to his friends in Italy, October 1846, fully sets forth the
deep laid plans by which Freemasonry sought to engage all classes.
" In <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> countries, it is by the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> we must go to
regeneration ; in yours, by the princes. We must absolutely make
them of our side. It is easy. The Pope will march in reform through
principle and of necessity ; the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> of Piedmont through the idea of
the crown of Italy; the Grand Duke of Tuscany through inclination
and irritation ; the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> of Naples through force ; and the little
princes will have to think of other <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">things</span> besides reform. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span>
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> in servitude can only sing its wants. Profit by the least
concession to assemble the masses, were it only to testify
gratitude.... Fetes, songs, assemblies, numerous relations
established among <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> of all opinions, suffice to make ideas gush
out, to give the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> a feeling of its strength and render it
exacting... Italy is still what France was before the Revolution ; she
wants, then, Mirabeau, Lafayette, and others. A <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">lord</span> may be
held back by his material interests, but he may be <span class="t7 t10 t12 t26 hoverable">taken</span> by vanity.
Leave him the chief <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> whilst he will go with you. There are few
who <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> go to the end.
" The essential <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t13 t15 t16 t20 t21 t22 t23 hoverable">thing</span> is, that the goal of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> revolution be
unknown to them ; let us never permit them to see more than the
first step. In Italy, the clergy are rich in money and the <span class="t4 t7 t12 t16 hoverable">faith</span> of the
people. You must

manage them in both those interests, and as much as possible
make their influence of use.
" Learned discussions are neither necessary nor opportune.
There are regenerative <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">words</span> which contain all that need be

tyranny, etc., etc.
" Nearly <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> <span class="t15 t23 hoverable">thousand</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> ago, a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> philosopher,
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> Christ, preached the fraternity which the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span>
seeks. Accept, then, all the help offered you. Whoever will
make one step towards you must be yours till he quits you. A
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">king</span> gives a more liberal <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">law</span> ; applaud him, and ask for the
one that must follow. A minister shows intention of progress ;
give him out as a model. A <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">lord</span> affects to pout at his
privileges ; put yourself under his direction if he will stop,
you will have <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> to let him go : he will remain isolated, and
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> strength against you, and you will have a <span class="t15 t23 hoverable">thousand</span>
ways to make unpopular all who oppose your projects. All
personal discontent, all deceptions, all bruised ambition, may
serve the cause of progress by giving them a. new direction.
The army is the greatest enemy to the progress of socialism.
It must be paralysed by the education of the people. Clerical
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> is personified in the Jesuits. The odium of that name is
already a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> for the socialists. Make <span class="t4 t18 hoverable">use</span> of it. Associate!
Associate! everything is in that word. The secret societies
give irresistible strength to the party that can <span class="t3 t11 t18 t27 hoverable">call</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> them.
Do not <span class="t28 hoverable">fear</span> to see them split: the more the better. All go to the
same end by different ways. The secret will be often violated ;
so much the better ; the secret is necessary to give security to
the members, but a certain transparency is needed to inspire
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> to the stationary.
Courage, then and persevere! "

OCCULT THEOCRASY

That Freemasonry has not always enjoyed immunity the
following quotation will serve to show.
" In the year 1735, the States General of Holland
proscribed the secret Masonic League, and the French
government imitated the example in 1735. In 1757, in
Scotland, the Synod of Stirling adopted a resolution debarring
all adhering Freemasons from the ordinances of religion.
" The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Great</span> Council of Berne proscribed Freemasonry in
1748, Bavaria followed in 1799, and its total suppression <span class="t0 t7 t11 t13 t14 t22 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">took</span>
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> in 1845, The Regency of Milan and the Governor of
Venice acted in a similar manner by it in 1814. John VI, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span>
of Portugal, prohibited Freemasonry in the strictest manner in
1816, and renewed it in 1824. In 1820 several lodges were
closed in Prussia for political intrigues ; and in the same year
Alexander I banished the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span> from the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> Russian
Empire. A similar occurrence <span class="t0 t7 t11 t13 t14 t22 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">took</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> four <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> later in
Modena and Spain... <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Yet</span> today, some <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> boast of belonging
to a secret society, the members of which were declared, by
an Act of George III, felons, and liable to transportation for
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> ! " 13
Speaking of Masons, in 1876, Richard Carlile wrote : " Let
them not wait to be disbanded by the Legislature, as a useless
and mischievous association : but let them anticipate the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span>
of a coming age... The deluge of mystery has not only
overwhelmed Babylon but Egypt, Greece, Rome, and will, if
we do not <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> up the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> of revelation in time, most
assuredly overthrow this British nation. It is even now in
danger, from the dissension of its internal mysteries, of
becoming an easy prey to some more barbarously mysterious
power. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Thus</span> fell Babylon, Egypt, Jerusalem, Greece,
13. Michael di Gargano, op. cit.

"Rome, and why not Britain, if Britain retain those seeds of

This warning however passed unheeded. During the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span>
that has elapsed between the publication of Car-lile's <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">book</span>
and the present day, we see England honeycombed with
societies, subversive of law, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span> and morals.
Numerous are the homes which have become resorts where,
today, the shameful orgies of Medmenham are enacted anew.
They are the secret haunts of social cliques and associations,
and behind such screens as art, antiques and dressmaking
thrive, as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> they were highly protected, the white slave
traffic, the dope traffic and gambling which serve as a
drag-net and decoy for the service of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Great</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> Pan.

GENERAL PEPE AND THE " ONE
BIG UNION "

At the present moment, when we are surfeited with the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">words</span> unions and mergers, to say nothing of cartels, a new
interest is awakened by the perusal of Thomas Frost's <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">book</span> on
Secret Societies, from which we extract the following :
" <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Two</span> results of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> importance in the progress of the
European revolution proceeded from the events that occurred
at Naples in 1820-21. One was the reorganization of the
Carbonari, consequent <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the publicity given to the system
when it had <span class="t0 t4 t6 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t19 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">brought</span> about the revolution, and the secrecy in
which it had hitherto been enveloped was no longer deemed
necessary ; the other was the extension of the system beyond
the Alps. When the Neapolitan revolution had been effected,
the Carbonari emerged from their mystery, published their
constitution and statutes, and ceased to conceal their patents
and their cards of membership. In the Papal States, in
Lombardy, and in Piedmont, the veil of secrecy was
maintained for a little <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> longer, partly through the
adoption by the Carbonari in those portions of the peninsula
of symbols and pass-words different from those of the
Neapolitan lodges, partly by the for200

mation of the various societies of the Adelphi, the Guelphs,

and consigned to oblivion. The scattered directors of the

conspiracy as soon as they were able, but with a new
nomenclature and a new symbolism. 1
" The dispersion of the Carbonaro leaders had, at the same
time, the effect of extending the system in France, where it
had been introduced towards the end of 1820 and creating
centres of revolutionary agitation in the foreign cities in
which they temporarily located themselves.
General Pepe proceeded to Barcelona when the
counter-revolution was imminent at Naples, and his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> was
no longer safe there ; and to the same <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">city</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">went</span> several of the
Piedmontese revolutionists when their country was
Austrianized after the same lawless fashion.
Scalvini and Ugoni <span class="t0 t7 t11 t13 t14 t22 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">took</span> refuge at Geneva ; others of the
proscribed proceeded to London. This dispersion, and the
progress which Carbonarism was making in France,
suggested to General Pepe the idea of an international secret
society, which should combine for a common purpose the
advanced political reformers of all the European States.
Shortly after his arrival at Madrid, to which <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">city</span> he
proceeded from Barcelona, he propounded to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> or
1. Thomas Frost, Secret Societies of the European Revolution,

OCCULT THEOCRASY

<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> ultra-Liberal deputies the plan of this society, the <span class="t2 hoverable">object</span>
of which, he says,
' was to enable the members to correspond and by these
means preclude the possibility of a renewal of that want of
union which had been experienced amongst the most noted
patriots of Spain and Portugal, Naples and Piedmont. Several
deputies of the Cortes were inclined to regard such an
association as extremely beneficial to the public cause, more
especially in their own peninsula, where a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> want of
concord existed between the Portuguese and the Spaniards.
The <span class="t1 hoverable">society</span> was accordingly founded; several members of the
Cortes formed part of it, as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> as General Ballesteros,
Councillor of State. I still preserve the regulations of this
society, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> <span class="t2 hoverable">object</span> of which was to open a communication
between the most enlightened patriots of the different cities in
Europe. It was decided that I should exert myself to give it
extension in Lisbon, London and Paris ; and that, in the event
of my success, other members should proceed to propagate it
over Italy and Germany. '
" Having organized in Madrid the first circle of the
Constitutional <span class="t1 hoverable">Society</span> of European Patriots, Pepe proceeded
to Lisbon, where he was even more successful in his efforts
than in the Spanish capital. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Two</span> of the Ministers, and several
Councillors of <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">State</span> and members of the Cortes signified their
adhesion, and, before Pepe left, a flourishing circle was
formed, under the direction of Almeida-Moraes, the president
of the Cortes. From Lisbon the general proceeded by sea to
London, where, as he says, he soon found that 'a secret <span class="t1 hoverable">society</span>
in England among <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> is a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t13 t15 t16 t20 t21 t22 t23 hoverable">thing</span> quite out of the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span> of probability '. He mentioned the <span class="t1 hoverable">society</span> to a few, but
met with no encouragement. The Duke of Sussex and Sir
Robert "Wilson read the statutes and regulations of the
society, but only as a <span class="t25 hoverable">matter</span> of curiosity. "

The Author of Secret Societies of the European Revolution

Who and what are the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> he refers to ?
Such indeed are the political principles adopted by the
leaders of Freemasonry. Therein lies its power. As soon as
any political movement becomes inevitable, as soon as public
pressure on an existing government becomes too strong, this
sect, in the name of Liberty, Equality and Fraternity, takes the
secret leadership of the opposing faction. Through the new
government which becomes the subservient tool of its
capricious master, who, at any moment, may suppress its
fledgling, by creating and backing a new opposition, it holds,
not the balance of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> but all the power.

In that year Masonry made an attempt to cast off the
Austrian yoke in Italy by using France as its base of
operations. Owing however to French non-cooperation the
revolution failed.
" A few <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t6 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 hoverable">days</span> afterwards, Misley and Linati arrived at
Marseilles and chartered a vessel, aboard which they put a
couple of cannon and twelve hundred muskets. They were
joined by General Pepe, Count Grilenzoni, the advocate
Mantovani, Dr. Franceschini, and Lieutenant Mori; but, at the
last moment, the Prefect received a telegraphic <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span> from
Paris to prevent their embarkation and lay an embargo on the

however, and contrived to reach Hyeres, where he <span class="t13 t14 t15 t18 t27 hoverable">heard</span> of
the entrance of the Austrians into Bologna, and thereupon
abandoned his intention of giving the aid of his reputation and
experience to the revolutionary cause. "
In connexion with the agitation provoked in Piedmont,
during the reign of Charles Albert, by Mazzini's " Young
Italy " movement in 1848, the veteran General Pepe again
comes into prominence. On March 29, 1848, he arrived at

and the Pope refusing permission for more than one battalion

There was much marching and countermarching but the

The tangled history of the " Young Italy " movement in its
early stages is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> explained by Thomas Frost in Secret

refer to this book. Due allowance must however be made for
certain omissions and inaccurate deductions on the part of the
author who, in 1876, could not have access to information
which is now available to anyone seeking it.

Adriano Lemmi wrote : " The anniversary of Sept. 20, the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> on which Rome became the capital of Italy, when the
temporal <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> of the Pope was overthrown, concerns
Freemasonry exclusively. It is an anniversary, a purely
masonic festival, which marks the date of the arrival of
Italian Freemasonry in Rome, the aim for which it had for
many <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> been striving. "
The date of Sept. 20, 1870, is not only an Italian date, it is
above all a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> masonic date, for it marks

the organization of a supreme rite, introduced into
Freemasonry, to lend a satanic character to the vague divinity
more or less <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> known by the name of " The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Great</span>
Architect of the Universe ".
During the last <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> preceding the capture of Rome,
Mazzini had established relations with the Masonic chief of
Scottish Rites, Albert Pike, President of the Supreme Council
of Charleston, United States.
Pike was a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> student of the Cabala and the occult.
Mazzini had understood that Freemasonry was a powerful
lever with which to revolutionize the world, but he saw it
divided into numerous rites, often rivals, and even hostile to
one another. Aspiring to Italian Unity as a means of breaking
the temporal <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Holy</span> See, he dreamt of a union of
masonry throughout the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> to destroy the church itself as a
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> power.
He addressed himself to Pike in preference to another
Grand Orient or Supreme Council chief because of the many
international ramifications of Ancient and Accepted Scottish
Rites, as Pike, its recognised chief, had succeeded in gaining
considerable influence over all the Supreme National
Councils of this rite which had hitherto been of a purely
dogmatic and liturgic character.
Mazzini, who was very practical, said that it <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be
inadvisable to favour one rite only to the exclusion of all the
others. In a letter to Albert Pike, dated Jan. 22, 1870, he writes.
" We must allow all the federations to continue just as they
are, with their systems, their central authorities and their
divers modes of correspondence between <span class="t23 hoverable">high</span> grades of the
same rite, organized as they are at present, but we must create
a supreme rite, which will remain unknown, to which

ALBERT PIKE AND GIUSEPPE MAZZINI

209

we will <span class="t3 t11 t18 t27 hoverable">call</span> those Masons of <span class="t23 hoverable">high</span> degree whom we shall
select. With regard to their brothers in masonry, these <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span>
must be pledged to the strictest secrecy. Through this
supreme rite, we will govern all Freemasonry which will
become the one international centre, the more powerful
because its direction will be unknown. "
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Thus</span> at the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> when Mazzini formed the scheme of
unifying Freemasonry by creating one central universal
direction reserved to a small <span class="t3 t17 t26 hoverable">number</span> of <span class="t23 hoverable">high</span> masons chosen
with the greatest care, he selected Albert Pike as an ally.
Pike was <span class="t16 t24 hoverable">born</span> in Boston on Dec. 29, 1809.
His parents, in modest circumstances, succeeded in giving
him a course at Harvard College. He then <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">went</span> to join his
family at Newbury port. There, for a while, he taught in a
primary school till he moved to Fair-haven where he
continued his career of pedagogue.
In 1833 he <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">went</span> to Little Rock.
From 1830 to 1840, Masonry in the United States had
fallen into disrepute and almost ceased to exist. After the
torture and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> of William Morgan in 1826, many lodges
faded into oblivion to resuscitate only after the storm of
public censure had abated.
During the Civil War, Pike served as brigadier-general in
the Confederate army. The Confederate government named
him Indian Commissioner and charged him with the conduct
of negotiations with the most powerful savage tribes, to raise
an army of their warriors. To facilitate his organization of this
army he was made Governor of Indian Territory, and once
these hordes were united, they were placed under his command. What followed can be easily understood as his troops
were composed of Chickasaws, Comanches,
Creeks, Cherokees, Miamis, Osages, Kansas and
Choc-aws, with all of whom he personally was on the best

210

OCCULT THEOCRASY

of terms. Among them, he was known as " the faithful
pale-face friend and protector ". It was no longer war — it
was an orgy of murder and atrocities so terrible that the
foreign powers interfered. Representations made by England,
threatening intervention in the name of humanity, finally
compelled Jefferson Davis to disband his auxiliary Indian
troops.
Mrs. Liliana Pike Room gives us the following chronological history of her father's early Masonic career. She says
that he became an Oddfellow, some <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> in the forties, and in
1850 entered the Masonic Fraternity. After that he gradually
ceased to be active as an Oddfellow. Soon becoming
prominent in Masonry he advanced rapidly to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">highest</span>
honours. His Masonic record is as follows :
" He was initiated in Western Star Lodge at Little Rock,
Arkansas, in 1850.
" Raised to the degree of Worshipful Master, in Western
Star Lodge No. 1, Little Rock, Arkansas, in July 1850.
" He became Charter Member of Magnolia Lodge, No. 60,
Little Rock, Arkansas, and was Worshipful <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t12 t17 t19 t20 t27 t29 hoverable">Master</span> ad vitam
of that lodge in 1853.

Arkansas, in 1850.
" Greeted as Royal and Select <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t12 t17 t19 t20 t27 t29 hoverable">Master</span> at Washington, D. C,
1852.
" <span class="t16 hoverable">Created</span> Knight Templar 1858 Washington
Com-mandary No. 1. K. T. in Washington.
" Elected Grand <span class="t23 hoverable">High</span> Priest of the Grand <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">Chapter</span> of

" In 1856, met Brother Theodor S. Parvin of Connecticut
and received degrees of A. A. (Ancient and Accepted Scottish

International Masons are already preparing the subversion of
the Socialist Labour movement.
" At the meeting in St. Martin's Hall, on September 28,
1864, when the ' International' was definitely founded, Marx
played no part at all. ' I was present', he wrote Engels, ' only as
a dumb personage on the platform'. Rut he was named
nevertheless a member of the sub-committee, the other
members being Mazzini's secretary— a Polish Jew named
Wolff — Le Lubez, a French Freemason, Cremer, the
secretary of the English Masons' Union, and Weston, the
Owenite. At the first meeting of this committee, Wolff placed
before it the statutes of Mazzini's Working-men's Association,
proposing them as the basis of the new association; Le Lubez
suggested amendments described by Marx as ' perfectly
childish '. ' I was firmly resolved ', he wrote, 'not to leave a
single line if possible of all their balderdash'. In a few weeks
he had succeeded in establishing his authority. ' My
propositions were all accepted by the commission.' "
As to <span class="t10 t12 t16 t20 t21 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">whether</span> Marx <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> manoeuvred himself into a
dominant position in the movement, or Mazzini's

ALBERT PIKE AND GIUSEPPE MAZZINI

219

agents manoeuvred Marx into this position to suit their own
ends, is <span class="t3 t13 t18 t24 hoverable">left</span> to our imagination, but the <span class="t24 hoverable">fact</span> of someone, not
an outstanding personality, being elected or nominated on a
committee for no particular reason, generally means, to
anyone versed in the technique of political tricks, that the
nomination or election was something arranged " behind the
scenes ".
On page 46 in La Theologie Politique de Mazzini et
I'lnternationale, Bakounine, the celebrated Russian anarchist,
refutes certain statements said to have been current in London
about himself at the time, in the following terms :
"But in 1864, while on my <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> through London, he (Karl
Marx) came to see me, and assured me that he (Mazzini) had
never <span class="t7 t10 t12 t26 hoverable">taken</span> any part direct or indirect in these calumnies
against me which he himself had considered most infamous. I
had to believe. "
It is a <span class="t24 hoverable">fact</span> that for a certain length of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> Mazzini and
Marx were closely associated.
An eminent Mason, the atheist leader of the Italian
Socialists, Alberto Mario, husband of Miss Jessie White, an
ardent Mazzinian and the authoress of a history of her hero —
Delia vita di Giuseppe Mazzini — was moreover a tool of
Pike whom he generally consulted on all important matters.
Thus, in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span> to divert the attention of the imperfect initiates,
Mazzini organized a congress of working <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> in Rome, in
October 1871. A close examination of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> of this
congress shows however that it was only pretence for nothing
practical was attempted or accomplished. On the other hand,
he busied himself with grouping all the political elements of
the sect in which occult manoeuvre his agent, Adriano
Lemmi, helped him more than anyone else.
" When Pike sent him a copy of his Luciferian rituals,
Mazzini was <span class="t5 hoverable">full</span> of an enthusiastic praise for his col-

Pike's literary achievements were numerous. These were,
Ariel, Morals and Dogma, The Sacred Hymns, The Sephar H.
Debarim, <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">Book</span> of the Word6, Legenda Magistralia, Ritual of

Satanic point of view.
The theological dogma of Albert Pike is explained in the '
Instructions ' issued by him, on July 14, 1889, to the 23
Supreme Councils of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> and have been recorded by A.

" Thus, the doctrine of Satanism is a heresy ; and the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span>

Darkness and Evil. "
One must not lose sight of the <span class="t24 hoverable">fact</span> that Pike occupied
simultaneously the positions of Grand <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t12 t17 t19 t20 t27 t29 hoverable">Master</span> of the Central
Directory of Washington, that of Grand Commander of the
Supreme Council of Charleston and that of Sovereign Pontiff

In 1880, a charter was granted himbythe Royal <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">Order</span> of

him Provincial Grand <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t12 t17 t19 t20 t27 t29 hoverable">Master</span> of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span> of H. R. M. He was
indeed a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> organizer.
Margiotta further writes:
" The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> secret chiefs, Pike and Mazzini, finally
completed the organization of <span class="t23 hoverable">high</span> masonry, establishing
four Grand Central Directories for the world, functioning
thenceforth to gather information for the benefit of their
political policy and dogmatic propaganda. These were, The
Grand Central Directories for North America at Washington,
for South America at Montevideo, for Europe at Naples, and
for Asia and Oceania at Calcutta. Later, a central
Sub-Directory for Africa was founded at Port Louis, Island of
Mauritius, and after the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> of Mazzini, the supreme chief
constituted a Universal Sovereign Administrative Directory
at Berlin which ranked in the hierarchy after the Sovereign
Executive Directories and before the four <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Great</span> Central
Directories. "
Gallatin Mackey, the confidant of Albert Pike, died in
Charleston on June 20, 1881. He was the author of many
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t29 hoverable">works</span> on masonry, namely The Lexicon of Freemasonry,
published in New York in 1845, The History of Freemasonry
in South Carolina, The Manual of the Lodge, The Masonic
Ritualist, The Symbolism of Freemasonry and The
Encyclopedia of Freemasonry, the authorship of which is
generally now attributed to Albert George Mackey.
According to the fundamental constitution of the
Palladium, the nomination of the Chief of Political Action,
the President of the Sovereign Executive Directory, was not
an elective office. Its incumbent was an appointee of the
Sovereign Pontiff of Universal Freemasonry.

When Mazzini felt himself to be dying, he designated
Adriano Lemmi as his successor. He died on March 11 1872,
at Pisa, and Albert Pike, deferring to his wishes, named
Adriano Lemmi as his successor.
Pike was not only an organizer and a politician, he was
also, in his religious capacity, as Cabalist and spiritist, a
mystic on <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> personality the following anecdote sheds a
flood of light.
" Speaking before the Supreme Council of Charles-ion, on
October 20, 1884, he gave an <span class="t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">account</span> of his recent travels
through the United States and some incidental experiences.
One of these, he described as follows : — 'At Saint Louis, we
operated the grand rites, and through Sister Ingersoll, who is
a first class medium, received astonishing revelations during
a solemn Palladian session at which I presided, assisted by
Brother Friedman and Sister Warhnburn. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Without</span> putting
Sister Ingersoll to sleep, we saturated her with the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> of
Ariel himself, but Ariel <span class="t0 t7 t11 t13 t14 t22 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">took</span> possession of her with 329 more
spirits of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> and the seance from then on was marvellous.
Sister Ingersoll, lifted into space, floated over the assembly
and her garments were suddenly devoured by a flame which
enfolded, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> burning her. We saw her <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> in a <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">state</span> of
nudity for over ten minutes. Flitting above our heads, as
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> borne by an invisible cloud, or upheld by beneficent
spirits, she answered all questions put to her. We <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> soon
had the latest news of our very illustrious brother Adriano
Lemmi. Then, Astaroth, in person, revealed himself, flying
beside our medium and holding her hand. He breathed <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span>
her and her clothes, returning from nowhere, clothed her
again. Finally Astaroth vanished and our sister fell gently on
to a chair where, with her <span class="t7 t11 t15 t22 hoverable">head</span> thrown back she gave up Ariel
and the 329 spirits who had accompanied him.

We counted 330 exhalations in all at the end of this most
successful experiment. " 7
A <span class="t3 t17 t26 hoverable">number</span> of books of this period refer to what must have
been a wireless telephone in the possession of the heads of the
Masonic organization. A translation of the detailed
description of this instrument, given in Ba-taille's book, is
quoted herewith as being of interest in these <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t6 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 hoverable">days</span> when magic
sometimes becomes experimental science. At the date on
which this description was first printed (1894) wireless was
unknown.
" In his house, Gallatin Mackey once showed me that
Arcula Mystica (the Mystic Box), of which there are only
seven examples in existence, at Charleston, Borne, Berlin,
Washington, Monte Video, Naples and Calcutta. 8
" The exterior of this small box resembles a liqueurs
receptacle. A spring catch opens simultaneously its <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> doors
and lid. Inside, in the middle, stands a telephone mouthpiece
in silver, which, at first sight, one <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">take</span> for a very small
trumpet or hunting horn. At the <span class="t3 t13 t18 t24 hoverable">left</span> is a little rope made of
twisted silver threads, one end of which is attached to the
machine while the other extremity ends in a, kind of little bell
which one holds to one's ear to hear the <span class="t23 hoverable">voice</span> of the <span class="t1 t8 t11 t16 t20 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">person</span>
with whom one is speaking, just like the telephone of today.
At the right is a toad, -in silver, with its mouth open. Placed
around the opening of the mouth-piece, stand seven statuettes
in gold, each on a small separate silver pedestal representing
symbolically the seven cardinal virtues of the Palladian
Ladder.
" Each of these seven statuettes designates one of the
Directories. The statuette Ignis (sacred fire) <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> endeavour,
stands for the Supreme Dogmatic Direc7. Bataille, Le Diable au XIX* siecle, p. 360 et seq.
8. Ibid, p. 391.

tory of Charleston ; Ratio (Reason, triumphant over

4. As to the seven rays :
Groups of Egos are formed :
1. According to their ray.
2. According to their sub-ray.
3. According to their rate of vibration.
They are also grouped for purposes of classification :
1. As Egos, according to the egoic ray.
2. As personalities, according to the subray which is
governing the personality. 13
" All are graded and charted. The Masters have Their Halls
of Records, with a system of tabulation incomprehensible to
us owing to its magnitude and its necessary intricacies
wherein these charts are kept. They are under the care of a
Chohan of a Ray, each Ray having its own collection of
charts... These Halls of Records are mostly on the lowest
levels of the mental plane and the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">highest</span> of the astral, as they
can be there most fully utilised and are most easily accessible.

William Morgan, the secret condemnation, kidnapping and

of Freemasonry, gives the following particulars : — " My
exposure of Freemasonry, in 1825, led to its exposure in the
United States of America; and a Mason there, of the name of
William Morgan, having announced his intention of assisting
in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> of exposure, was kidnapped, under pretended
forms and warrants of law, by his brother Masons, removed
from the <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">State</span> of New York to the borders of Canada, near
the falls of Niagara, and there most barbarously murdered.
This happened in 1826. The States have been for many <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span>
much excited <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the subject; a regular warfare has arisen
between Masons and anti-Masons. Societies of anti-Masons
have been formed, newspapers and magazines started, and
many pamphlets and volumes, with much correspondence,
published ; so that before the slavery question was passed
amongst them, all parties had merged themselves into
Masons and anti-Masons. Several persons were punished for
the abduction of Morgan : but the murderers were sheltered
by Masonic Lodges, and rescued from justice. "

historical <span class="t24 hoverable">fact</span> ; but in August, 1875, the <span class="t5 hoverable">full</span> particulars were
<span class="t0 t4 t6 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t19 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">brought</span> to <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> by the publication of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> letters from the

When the boat reached the point where Niagara River

pretence, and with some horrible mummeries ordered Morgan to prepare for death. They wound a rope around him,
attaching to each end of it a heavy weight, and threw him
overboard. He sank like a stone, and the murderers returned
to tell their comrades that the traitor had met a traitor's doom.

Nowadays, greater precautions are observed in getting rid

But to return to the organization of Freemasonry.
It is necessary here to say that in many instances, where a
masculine lodge has a feminine annex, its <span class="t11 t16 hoverable">existence</span> is
frequently completely ignored by the majority of the brothers.
No mutual visiting is allowed among the female members of
the lower masonic degrees, for a sister may enter lodges other
than her own, only after she has herself attained the fifth
degree. As <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span>
