— HRDM and RYCS — or those of Heredom and Rosy
Cross.
The antiquity and origin of " Mother Kilwinning " is a
favourite theme with Masonic authors according to whom the
degree of Heredom of Kilwinning was founded in the reign of
<span class="t6 t11 t13 t14 t15 t22 t23 t28 hoverable">David</span> I, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> of Scotland, and that of Rosy Cross by Robert
Bruce in 1314.
Robert Freke Gould, however, places the date of the
foundation of the Royal <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">Order</span> of Scotland in " the middle of
the last century ", and gives us the name of William Mitchell,
a Scotsman who obtained his patent as its founder from the
Provincial Grand <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t12 t17 t19 t20 t27 t29 hoverable">Master</span> of South Britain on July 22, 1750. l

XLIV

OBSERVANCE

(Founded 1751-52)
The following main facts concerning the Strict Observance
are mostly gathered from the profusely documented <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> of
R. Le Forestier who, having made a comprehensive study of
the subject, <span class="t0 t7 t11 t13 t14 t22 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">took</span> as one of his chief authorities Nettelbladt.
The Templar rite of the Strict Observance was founded in
1751 by Charles Gotthelf, Baron de Hund (born 1722)
Chamberlain and Councillor of the Elector of Saxony, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span>
of Poland, as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> as Councillor of the Empress Maria
Theresa.
In 1764, the Anglo-Jewish adventurer Leucht, variously
known as Johnson, de Martin, Robert de Leich-ten, Becher,
Despocher, de Bousch, Somery, Scheel and Koenig, made an
attempt to amalgamate the Templar System of Clermont, the
control of which he had seized the previous year from Rosa,
with that of von Hund, with the <span class="t1 t2 t19 hoverable">view</span> of dominating the latter
also. In this he failed.
Rosa had been the Legate for Germany, Holland and the
kingdoms of the north while, in Paris, the Comte de Clermont
occupied a similar position with regard to France, Spain,
Portugal and Italy.

The legend of the Strict Observance is very much involved.
Stating that the Stuarts were the unknown superiors of the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">Order</span> it claimed descent from Pierre d'Aumont, Banneret
d'Auvergne, at the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> of the Grand <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t12 t17 t19 t20 t27 t29 hoverable">Master</span>
Jacques de Molay and the successor of Beaujeu, Molay's
nephew who, with <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> Commanders and five Knights had
escaped to the Island of Mull where they encountered George
Harris, the Grand Commander of Hampton Court, likewise a
refugee. They elected d'Aumont Grand <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t12 t17 t19 t20 t27 t29 hoverable">Master</span> and adopted
the costume and customs of Masons in memory of d'Aumont
and his companions who, for <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> years, had lived <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> in
disguise while exercising the trade to earn a livelihood. Not
daring to recruit openly, the Templars were eventually
permitted to marry to perpetuate the order. For over 250 years,
admission to the degree of Scotch <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t12 t17 t19 t20 t27 t29 hoverable">Master</span> had been restricted
to the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t6 t7 t13 t14 t15 t20 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">sons</span> of Templars and only <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">within</span> the last 150 <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> had

of <span class="t8 t11 t14 t19 hoverable">free</span> parents. D'Aumont was succeeded as Grand <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t12 t17 t19 t20 t27 t29 hoverable">Master</span> by
Harris. " 1

ILLUMINATI

XLVI
OF

AVIGNON

(Founded 1760)

The Illuminati of Avignon were founded in 1760 by
Antoine Joseph Pernety, an unfrocked Benedictine, a Cabalist
and alchemist. Modified in 1766 by Chas-tanier, one of the
founders of the English Rite of Swedenborg, this rite was
introduced into Paris in the Lodge Socrates of Perfect Union
under the name of Theosophical Illumines. In 1770, Pernety,
founded La Grande Loge Ecossaise du Comtat Venaissin.
This Lodge was raided in 1774 and its papers confiscated by
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span> of the Pope. It was revived in 1789 \
Among its members were Cagliostro and his friend Baron
de Corberon, Mesmer, Marquis de Thome and the Marquis de
Puysegur, self-styled Professor of " Mesmerism ".
In Les Illumines d'Avignon by Joanny Bricaud (page 103)
we read that " today, its members having become affiliated to
Martinism, the <span class="t1 hoverable">society</span> has ceased to exist ". This author also
states that the degree of Knight of

In 1804, in France, a Supreme Council of Sovereign Grand
Inspectors General of the 33rd degree of the Antient and
Accepted Scottish Rite was duly constituted. In the
construction of this Council, Comte Alexandre F. A. de
Grasse-Tilly, (the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">son</span> of the Admiral) played a leading part.
He had been initiated in Paris several <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> before he <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">went</span> to
America where we <span class="t11 t12 t22 t25 t27 hoverable">find</span> him a colonist of San Domingo.
His successor was the Due Decazes.
As regards the development of Scottish Rites in England,

over the degrees of the ' Rose-Croix ' and ' Kadosch, ' which

in some of the older English encampments.

<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">ORDER</span>

OF

XLVIII
THE

MOPSE

(Founded 1763)
Pope Clement XIV having excommunicated the
Freemasons in 1763, many German Catholics, frightened by
the Papal Bull, definitely renounced the society.
They formed however another association which, while
restoring their former organization, should not expose them to
the censure of the Vatican and, having found a protector in the
<span class="t1 t8 t11 t16 t20 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">person</span> of one of the most august German Sovereigns of the
day, they secured an influential German nobleman as Grand
Master. Many distinguished persons joined the " new " <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span>
which, like the Freemasons, had laws, words, signs of recognition, reception ceremonies and appointed officers.
One of the principal lodges was at Frankfort.
Adherence to the Roman Catholic <span class="t4 t7 t12 t16 hoverable">faith</span> was declared a
requisite of membership, but the rule was not enforced and as
a protection from papal excommunication a promise, instead
of an oath of secrecy, was exacted from candidates.
Women were eligible to any dignity in the order, excepting
that of Grand Master, which position was held for life. There
were <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> Lodge Masters or Grand
365

366

Mopses in each lodge, one of which was a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> and one a
woman, while the lodge was governed six months by a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span>
and six months by a woman alternately, 1

Mopse, and resembled a rather large pug dog with a curly tail.
" During the ceremony the candidates were admitted
blindfolded and were instructed to kiss something. This was
nothing more nor less than a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> sized model of a mopse, and
on the bandage being removed the initiate found that he or she
had kissed the tail end of the dog. <span class="t10 t12 t16 t20 t21 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">Whether</span> the ceremonies
were merely boisterous fooling, or <span class="t10 t12 t16 t20 t21 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">whether</span> they had any
esoteric significance it is difficult to say, as students differ on
the point.
" The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">Order</span> was certainly at one <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> wide spread and
popular, but seems to have entirely died out. Probably its

societies into disrepute, owing ta the supposed share of the
Illuminati in starting that tremendous upheaval. "

CHAPTER
THE RITE

XLIX

OF ZINNENDORF

(Founded 1766)
This rite was founded in 1766 by Zinnendorf, the chief
surgeon of the general staff of Berlin and a Knight
Commander in von Hund's Strict-Observance. Zinnendorf
received the rituals and instructions for this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span> from a
Swede named Cklack.
On Dec. 27 1770, Zinnendorf formed a Grand Lodge in
Berlin with the cooperation of twelve lodges which had
adopted his opinions. On March 29 of the following year, he
demanded a constitution from the Grand Lodge of London.
This he finally obtained in 1773 through the influence of
Prince Louis George Charles of Hesse-Darmstadt, the Grand
<span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t12 t17 t19 t20 t27 t29 hoverable">Master</span> of the Lodges following his system. l
The Rite of Zinnendorf was absorbed at the Convent of
Wolfenbuttel in 1778 into the Lodge of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Three</span> Globes of
Berlin.
1. Revue Internationale des Societes Secretes, Nov. 19, May 6,
1928. p. 397.

and others.

As the organization of the Illuminati developed, so did its
ambitions, which ended in a plot to subvert Freemasonry to
its aim of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> dominion by any and all means.
Politically speaking, its tendencies were republican ;
religiously, it was anti-christian. Its members were pledged to
blind obedience to their superiors and this was insured by a
strict system of secret confessions, and monthly reports
checked by mutual espionage. Each individual <span class="t4 hoverable">used</span> a
pseudonym instead of his own name to help disguise his
identity.
But for the Freemason Baron Adolph von Knigge, a
Templar, who succeeded in having it absorbed by
Freemasonry, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> have perished soon after its
creation.
After obtaining control of certain Masonic Lodges,
Weishaupt and his associates recklessly vaunted their
growing power. Their organization then, soon becoming
permeated by the agents of their enemies, the Jesuits and
Rose Croix Orders, they were denounced to the Elector of
Bavaria, Charles Theodore, by the Duchess Marie-Anne of
Bavaria (Princess Clementine), his cousin <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> secretary,

More papers were found when the authorities, who were

Ingolstadt, decided to raid the place, and in 1787 the judge
charged with the inventory of the succession of the valet of
Baron Maendl, the Chamberlain of the Elector, found among
his effects an iron box <span class="t5 hoverable">full</span> of papers concerning the
Illuminati.

summoned to explain. Among the details of his evidence is
the statement that the Lodge Bader had 97 degrees. The
coincidence of this <span class="t3 t17 t26 hoverable">number</span> becomes of interest when
compared with the 97 degrees of Memphis sent to England
in 1762 by the Grand Orient of France.
When Weishaupt was banished from Bavaria by his
sovereign, he was received at the court of the Duke
Ernest-Louis de Saxe-Gotha who, besides a pension, gave
him the title of Honorary Councillor.

successor of <span class="t15 t23 hoverable">Moses</span> Mendelssohn. Noted Illuminati were

Graetz, the Jewish historian, wrote :

Midianite tent. Here a <span class="t3 t17 t26 hoverable">number</span> of young Jewish women
assembled <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> husbands were kept away by their business.

Frederick von Gentz, the embodiment of selfishness,

was the betrayal of women. l

Later, in 1807, a <span class="t2 t3 t5 t10 t12 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">second</span> Tugendbund or Union of Virtue

" The nucleus of the Association devised by von Stein
which received the name of the Tugendbund, or League of
Virtue, was formed during the latter months of 1807. His
colleagues, Hardenberg and Scharnhorst; Generals
Wittgenstein and Blucher ; Jahn, a Professor of the Berlin
Gymnasium, and Arndt, the popular author, were amongst the
earliest members. The initiations multiplied rapidly, and the
League soon numbered in its ranks most of the Councillors of
State, many officers of the army, and a considerable <span class="t3 t17 t26 hoverable">number</span> of
the professors of literature and science. By the active and
zealous exertions of Stein, Hardenberg and Jahn, its
ramifications spread quickly from the Baltic to the Elbe, and
all classes were drawn <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">within</span> its influence. A central

control of the movement, and exercised, through provincial
committees, an authority all the more potent from emanating
from an unknown source, and which was obeyed as implicitly
as the decrees of Emperor or King. " 3
3. Thomas Frost, Secret Societies of the European Revolution,

OCCULT THEOCRASY

With Heckethorn, we follow the Tugendbund further,
for he tells us that after its suppression by the police of
Napoleon I, the Tugendbund continued " concealing
itself however more strictly than before in the masonic
brotherhood. " 4
One of its first acts " was to send auxiliary corps to assist
the Russians in the campaign of 1813. Prussia having, by the
course of events, been compelled to abandon its temporizing
policy, Gneisenau, Scharn-horst and Grollmann embraced
the military plan of the Tugendbund. A levy en masse was
ordered. The conduct of these patriots is <span class="t25 hoverable">matter</span> of history.
But, like other nations, they fought against Napoleon to
impose on their country a more tyrannical government than
that of the foreigner had ever been. They fought as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> only
fight for a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> cause, and those who died fancied they saw
the dawn of German freedom. But those who survived saw
how much they were deceived. The Tugendbund, betrayed in
its expectations, was dissolved ; but its members increased
the ranks of other societies already existing, or about to be
formed " such as the ' Black Knights ' under Jahn, ' The
Knights of the Queen of Prussia ', ' The Concor-dists ' under
Dr. Lang and the Deutscher Bund, founded in 1810."
The Tugendbund was revived in the Burschens-chaft, or
associations of students of the universities, where they
introduced gymnastics and martial exercises, but the
organization was broken up and its objects frustrated, after
the stabbing of Kotzebue by a student. It revived between
1830-33. It is said to have failed again.

JACOBINS

(THE CLUBS OR LODGES OF THE FRENCH REVOLUTION).

(Founded 1786)
The Bishop of Autun (Talleyrand), Mirabeau, and the Due
d'Orleans, Grand <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t12 t17 t19 t20 t27 t29 hoverable">Master</span> of the Grand-Orient de France
founded a Lodge in Paris in 1786 which was duly "
illuminated " by Bode and Guillaume Baron de Busche. This
was the Club Breton which afterwards became known as the
Jacobin Club, a name of Templar origin, recalling that of
Jacques de Molay.
Le Forestier in Les Illumines de Baviere et la
Franc-Magonnerie Allemande gives the substance of a <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">book</span>
<span class="t0 t11 t24 hoverable">written</span> by Girtaner, quoting the latter as to the funds
available at that date for revolution.
" In his Nouvelles Historiques et considerations poli-tiques
sur la Revolution Frangaise (1793) the Swiss Girtaner, an
ex-freemason who had joined the ranks of the enemies of the
sect, states that, from 1786, there had existed in Paris a
Propaganda Club <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> chiefs were then the Due de la
Rochefoucauld, Grand <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t12 t17 t19 t20 t27 t29 hoverable">Master</span> of the Lodge in the rue
Coq-Heron, Condorcet and Sieyes and that the aim of the
organization was to further the triumph of dogmatic Atheism
and create a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> social upheaval.

" The members charged with spreading the pro-ganda of

The conspiracy formed by Philippe of Orleans (Due de
Chartres, Masonic name, " Egalite ") to overthrow Louis XVI,
was directed by Sillery and Mirabeau and, of the 605 elected
members of the Tiers Etat, 477 deputies were Freemasons. 2
Revolutions cost money. " L'Or de Pitt" (Pitt's gold) had to
go through some channel that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> not compromise the

Stanhope, Pitt's brother-in-law.

Bantry Bay expedition is interesting.

According to Barruel (Histoire du Jacobinisme, vol. II,
page 446 et seq.) the last mentioned lodge of the " Amis des
Noirs " appears to have been only the cover name behind
which operated the Comite Regulateuf or Central Committee
of the combined lodges and clubs. An international
organization with foreign branches in America and Europe,
the deliberations of this group of conspirators were sent to the
Central Committee of the Grand Orient from where they were
relayed to the provinces, addressed to the various Worshipful
Masters or Presidents of the Lodges. This group according to
Barruel, was the central guiding committee of the Revolution.
The " Club Regulateur " is said to have numbered at least
500,000 brothers.

After the storm of revolution had subsided, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> in

leaders. That they in turn were controlled by a small clique is
obvious. Even the 300 masonic leaders of the French
Revolution of 1793 seem to have had their successors in
modern history — Rathenau mentioned them in his works.
One of the most interesting episodes of the French
Revolution was that known as the Conspiracy of Babeuf.
Babeuf formed the <span class="t1 hoverable">Society</span> of the Pantheon which, according
to Professor Laski, 6 was operated by " a secret committee of
direction. Among them were some extraordinary men,
Darthe, Sylvain Marechal, Germain and Buonarroti, who was
to survive them all and be their historian. "
The particular brand of communism favoured by the
conspirators was based on the theory that the poor could not
help themselves or improve their position, that the rich must
be suppressed and that the ideal <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">state</span>

THE KNIGHTS TEMPLAR
AMERICA
(Foundedprior to 1790)

In an address by Col. W. J. B. Macleod Moore, of the
Grand Cross of the Temple Royal Arch, Grand Prior of the
Dominion of Canada, published in The Rosicrucian and
Masonic Record, page 167, we <span class="t11 t12 t22 t25 t27 hoverable">find</span> that, in America,
Templarism is founded on the craft degrees of Masonry and
that one is inseparable from the other.
The earliest records in the United States of a Templar
Lodge meeting are dated 1790.

THE UNITED IRISHMEN
(Founded 1791)
In 1791, the <span class="t1 hoverable">Society</span> of The United Irishmen was founded
by Theobald Wolfe Tone and Napper Tandy, both of whom
were <span class="t23 hoverable">high</span> in rank in the Masonic lodges. The organization
sought to unite Catholics, Protestants and Dissenters in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span>
to throw off the oppressive yoke of England or, to <span class="t4 t18 hoverable">use</span> the
graphic language of Tone himself, " to subvert the tyranny of
our execrable government, to break the connection with
England, the never-failing source of all our political evils,
and to assert the independence of my country — these were
my objects. To unite the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> of Ireland. " l
The priesthood and the nobles however stood solidly
behind the English <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> ; but the social conditions imposed
by England on its Irish-Catholic subjects rendered that
country a fertile soil for the sowing of the Revolutionary seed.
These disabilities are described by Lecky in the following
article which appeared in Macmillan's Magazine, January,
1873.
" To sum up briefly their provisions, they (the English)
excluded the Catholics from the Parliament,
1.

The Autobiography of Wolfe Tone, p. 51.
385

386

from the magistracy, from the corporations, from the
university, from the bench and from the bar, from the right of
voting at parliamentary elections or at vestries of acting as
constables, as sheriffs, or as jurymen, of serving in the army
or navy, of becoming solicitors or even holding the position
of gamekeeper or watchman. They prohibited them from
becoming schoolmasters, ushers, or private tutors, or
from sending their <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">children</span> abroad to receive the Catholic
education they were refused at home. They offered an
annuity to every priest who <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> forsake his creed,
pronounced a sentence of exile against the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> hierarchy,
and restricted the right of celebrating the mass to registered
priests, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> number, according to the first intention of the
Legislature, was not to be renewed. The Catholics could not
buy land, or inherit or receive it as a gift from Protestants, or
hold <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> annuities, or leases for more than thirty-one years, or
any lease on such terms that the profits of the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">land</span> exceeded
one-third of the rent. A Catholic, except in the linen trade,
could have no more than <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> apprentices. He could not have
a horse of the value of more than £5, and any Protestant on
giving him £5 might <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">take</span> his horse. He was compelled to pay
double to the militia. In <span class="t1 t3 t5 t16 t19 t25 hoverable">case</span> of war with a Catholic Power,
he was obliged to reimburse the damage done by the enemy's
privateers. To convert a Protestant to Catholicism was a
capital offence. No Catholic might marry a Protestant.
Into his own family circle the elements of dissension were
ingeniously introduced. A Catholic landowner might not
bequeath his <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">land</span> as he pleased. It was divided equally
among his children, unless the eldest <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">son</span> became a
Protestant, in which <span class="t1 t3 t5 t16 t19 t25 hoverable">case</span> the parent became simply a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span>
tenant, and lost all <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> either of selling or mortgaging it. If a
Catholic s wife abandoned her husband's religion, she was

The history of the United Irishmen is largely the history of
Theobald Wolfe Tone.

after which Tone remarks " Mode of doing business by a

co-operating, but who, in fact, direct the movements of
Belfast. "

ceeds to make the following observation : — « The enormous

Suppressed in 1794, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span> had reorganized in 1795 as a

In 1795, having become seriously implicated in the
treasonable activities of the Rev. William Jackson, an
emissary of the French Government to the Irish Revolutionaries, Tone <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">went</span> to America where he saw the French
Minister Citizen Adet. With his approval and instructions,
Wolfe Tone sailed for France on Jan. 1, 1796 where he spent
the remainder of his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t6 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 hoverable">days</span> planning the downfall of England.
He held that " unless they can separate England from Ireland,
England is invulnerable. " 4
From the beginning of his French intrigues, he feared
treason to his cause and, in his diary, we <span class="t11 t12 t22 t25 t27 hoverable">find</span> the following
entry dated March 21, 1796, quoting General Clark in a
conversation he had just had with him :

Six months after his arrival in Paris, Tone received a
commission in the French army, and with the assistance of the
Directory, General Hoche and others organized the ill fated
Bantry Bay expedition of 1796. Every effort to thwart their
plans was made by the French navy till, as Tone tells us in an
entry dated Nov. 14 to 18, " Villaret de Joyeuse, the Admiral,
is cashiered, and we have got another in his place. Joyeuse
was giving, underhand, all possible impediment to our
expedition. "

Did Wolfe Tone think of Vergennes then ? History fails to
tell us !
The activities of The United Irishmen ended with the
uprising of 1798 and another attempt by the French to <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">land</span>
troops on Irish soil. This rebellion was however also crushed,
and Wolfe Tone, who was <span class="t7 t10 t12 t26 hoverable">taken</span> prisoner and ordered to be
hanged, cut his throat in his cell.

(Founded 1795)
The Battle of the Diamond between the Peep-o'-Day Boys
and the Defenders <span class="t0 t7 t11 t13 t14 t22 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">took</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> on Sept. 21, 1795.

information in The Secret Societies of Ireland from which we
quote :
" On the evening of the battle a <span class="t3 t17 t26 hoverable">number</span> of the delegates of
the Peep-o'-Day Boys met at the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">house</span> of Thomas Wilson at
Loughgall. There and then the name of the <span class="t1 hoverable">Society</span> was
changed to The Orange Society, and a grand lodge and
subsidiary lodges initiated. The ritual was founded on
Freemasonry (1° York Rite), and the legend was that of the
Exodus of the Israelites.
" The original Peep-o'-Day <span class="t1 hoverable">Society</span> had been confined to
the lower orders, but with the change in Orangeism the upper
classes began to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">take</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> and rank in the organization which
was secretly fostered by the Government as a counter-poise
against the seditious United Irishmen. l "

Grand Mastership of the Duke of Cumberland, and in 1835

and branches were in many of the colonies.
" The conspiracy prospered from 1828 to 1835, when it

<span class="t1 hoverable">Society</span> in England <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> recourse to violence. "
" The Volunteer movement began in 1914 in Ulster as the

CHAPTER

LVII

THE PHILADELPHIANS
(THE OLYMPIANS)

(Founded 1798)

The Philadelphians, a Royalist Anti-Bonapartist Secret
Society, was founded on masonic lines about 1798 at
Besancon, France, by General Malet and organized by a
Freemason, Lieutenant Colonel Oudet.
Using England as a base of operations, it cooperated for a
while with the " Chouans " <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> chief, Pichegru, was
eventually captured and executed by <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span> of the Directory.
After this event, the Philadelphians adopted the name of
The Olympians. Most of them however, including Oudet,
were shot from ambush the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> after the battle of Wagram,
the responsibility for their deaths being placed on Napoleon I.
In 1812 General Malet formed a conspiracy to overthrow
the Empire. Among those implicated were Generals Moreau,
Talleyrand, Trochot, the Comte de Noailles, the Comte de
Montmorency and Fouche, who was then under the cloud of
Napoleon's displeasure. General Massena, Grand <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t12 t17 t19 t20 t27 t29 hoverable">Master</span> of
the Grand Orient, who at that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> was in disgrace, was to
have been offered the command of the troops. This daring
plot
395

396

OCCULT THEOCRASY

almost succeeded and Fouche says that Malet carried with
him to the grave " the secret of one of the boldest conspiracies
which the Grand Epoch of the Revolution has bequeathed to
history. " 1
General Moreau, who had gone to settle in America
returned to France in 1813, the last of the leaders of the
Olympians. He died Sept. 2 from a wound received some
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t6 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 hoverable">days</span> earlier.
A few moments after the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> of Moreau, the Senate
pronounced the deposition of Napoleon and carried out the
programme of the Olympians.
1. Thomas Frost, The Secret Societies of the European Revolution, vol. I, p. 175.

THE SCOTTISH PHILOSOPHIC RITE

Rev. E. Cahill, S. J., in his <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">book</span> Freemasonry and the

" The Scottish Philosophic Rite is practised by the Masons
subject to the Lodge Alpina in Switzerland. This latter Grand
Lodge, which is among those formally recognized by the
Grand Lodges of the British Isles, is of special importance, as
it is not unfrequently utilised as a kind of liaison <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> by the

the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> in their negotiations with each other. "

MODERN KNIGHTS TEMPLAR ENGLAND
(Founded 1804)
In an address by Col. W. J. B. Macleod Moore, of the
Grand Cross of the Temple Royal Arch, Grand Prior of the
Dominion of Canada, printed in The Rosi-crucian and
Masonic Record (page 165), we obtain the following salient
points of English Templar history :
" In 1791, we <span class="t11 t12 t22 t25 t27 hoverable">find</span> the Templar Rite styled ' Grand Elect
Knights Templar Kadosh, of St. John of Jerusalem, Palestine,
Rhodes, and Malta', <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> combining the modern and more
ancient titles... In 1848 after the Ancient and Accepted
Scottish Rite of 33° had been established in England, the
Templar <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> resigned control over the Rose Croix and
Kadosh, which had been incorporated into the Ancient and
Accepted Rite as the 18th and 30th degrees. It was <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span>
necessary to suppress the old ceremonies and confine
themselves to the Templar alone and to change the name into
the degree of ' Masonic Knights Templar '. This title was not
<span class="t4 hoverable">used</span> in England before 1851, although the term Masonic
appears in the warrants of Admiral Dunkerley
399

400

OCCULT

THEOCRASY

between 1791 1 and 1796... Until 1853 the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">Order</span> of the
Temple and Malta remained combined.
" In 1863 the Grand Conclave again formally revived the
Maltese Order, with a considerable ritual, but as a separate
degree instead of combined with the Templars as it had been
before 1853. "
The following, borrowed from The History of Freemasonry
and Concordant Orders, a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> by Stillson and Hughan,
reputed authorities on Masonic matters, gives us the history of
Modern English Templarism.
" In 1867-68 a proposal was promulgated to unite the
branches of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">Order</span> in England, Ireland and Scotland, under
one <span class="t7 t11 t15 t22 hoverable">head</span> ; andH.-. R.\ II.-. the Prince of Wales, who had been
initiated into Masonry and the Templar degree in Sweden,
consented, in 1869, to assume the Grand Mastership of the
Templars of the United Kingdom. On the 7th April, 1873,
II.-. R.\ H.\
was installed Grand Master... This assumption by II.-. R.-. II.-.
the Prince of Wales, to <span class="t4 t18 hoverable">use</span> the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">words</span> of the Arch-Chancellor
of the Order, Sir Patrick Col-quhoun, ' effected a perfect
reformation of the Order, and procured for it a status it had
hitherto not enjoyed, even under the Duke of Kent, who must
be practically regarded as its founder, with the additional
advantage of H.\ R.\ II.-. being at once <span class="t7 t11 t15 t22 hoverable">head</span> of the Craft and
Temple ; indeed, it may be said that as the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">Order</span> was
reformed in 1804-7 by the Duke of Kent, so it was again
refounded under his grandson, the Prince of Wales, in 1873 '.
At this date the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">Order</span> assumed the name of United Religious
and Military <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">Order</span> of the Temple and of St. John of Jerusalem,
Palestine, Rhodes and Malta. "

MODERN KNIGHTS TEMPLAR FRANCE
(Founded 1804)
Heckethorn in his well-known <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">book</span> Secret Societies of all
Ages and Countries gives the following graphic description
of the foundation of this order.
" We read that several lords of the Court of Louis XIV,
including the Duke de Gramont, the Marquis of Biran, and
Count Tallard, formed a secret society, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> <span class="t2 hoverable">object</span> was
pleasure. The <span class="t1 hoverable">society</span> increased. Louis XIV, having been
made acquainted with its statutes, banished the members of
the Order, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> denomination was, ' A slight Resurrection
of the Templars. '
" In 1705, Philippe, Duke of Orleans, l collected the
remaining members of the <span class="t1 hoverable">society</span> that had renounced its first
scope to cultivate politics. A Jesuit father, Bonanni, a learned
rogue, fabricated the famous list of supposititious Grand
Masters of the Temple since Molay, beginning with his
immediate successor, Larmenius. No imposture was ever
sustained with greater sagacity. The document offered all the
requisite characteristics of authenticity, and was calculated to
deceive the most
1. Later Regent of France during the minority of Louis XV.
402

MODERN KNIGHTS TEMPLAR FRANCE

403

experienced palaeologist. Its <span class="t2 hoverable">object</span> was to connect the new
institution with the ancient Templars. To render the deception
more perfect, the volume containing the false list was filled
with minutes of deliberations at fictitious meetings under
false dates. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Two</span> members were even sent to Lisbon, to obtain
if possible a document of legitimacy from the ' Knights of
<span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t16 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Christ</span> ', an <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">Order</span> supposed to have been founded on the ruins
of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">Order</span> of the Temple. But the deputies were unmasked
and very badly received : one had to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">take</span> refuge in England,
the other was transported to Africa, where he died.
" But the <span class="t1 hoverable">society</span> was not discouraged; it grew, and was
probably the same that concealed itself before the outbreak of
the revolution under the vulgar name of the <span class="t1 hoverable">Society</span> of the
Bull's <span class="t7 t11 t15 t22 hoverable">Head</span> and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> members were dispersed in 1792. At
that period the Duke of Cosse-Brissac was Grand Master.
When on his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> to Versailles with other prisoners, there to
undergo their trial, he was massacred, and Ledru, his
physician, obtained possession of the charter of Larmenius
and the MS. statutes of 1705. These documents suggested to

RITE OF MIZRAIM
(Founded 1805)

This rite had 90 degrees. It was founded in 1805 at Milan
by Le Changeur, Gavel, Marc Bedarride and Joly, and was
introduced into France in 1816.
Its trials of initiation were <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> and difficult, and founded
on what is recorded of the Egyptian and Eleusinian mysteries.
Heckethorn states that this rite is essentially autocratic
there being no obligation on the Grand <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t12 t17 t19 t20 t27 t29 hoverable">Master</span> to <span class="t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">account</span> for

philosophic Masonic Rite (Ancient and Primitive Rite of
Mizraim) has been recently established in England under

90° ; the Rt. Hon. The Earl of Limerick 90°; and S. Rosenthal

Maurice Joly (1831-1878), was <span class="t16 t24 hoverable">born</span> at Lons-le-Saul-nier.
His mother, nee Florentine Corbara Courtois, was a Corsican
of Italian origin and a Roman Catholic. Her father, Laurent
Courtois, had been paymaster-general of Corsica. He had an
inveterate hatred of Napoleon I.
Joly's <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">father</span> was Philipe Lambert Joly, <span class="t16 t24 hoverable">born</span> at Dieppe,

was educated at Dijon and began his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">law</span> studies there, but
in 1849 he <span class="t3 t13 t18 t24 hoverable">left</span> for Paris.

Joly was a Socialist. He wrote of himself: " Socialism
seems to me one of the forms of a new <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> for the peoples

Friend of Adolphe Cremieux, he shared in his hatred of

such in his pamphlet.
In one of his books he wrote of it :

We are again indebted to Captain Pollard for a sketch of its

a renaissance of the old agrarian Catholic secret societies
which had been absorbed into the Defenders and thence into
the United Irishmen. The provisions of the Insurrection Act
which forbade the possession of arms and enforced a curfew
at nightfall were in operation until 1805, when with its relaxation appears the Ribbon Society... In different counties local
organizations of Ribbon <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> themselves by different
titles, such as the Threshers, the Carders, the Molly Maguires,
Rockites, Caravats, Shanavests, Pauddeen Gar's <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> and the
like. " l

RITE (ANCIENT AND

(Founded 1808)
The following article is quoted in part from an article specifically
<span class="t0 t11 t24 hoverable">written</span> by Josiah H. Drummond 33° in The History Of Freemasonry
and Concordant Orders by Stillson and Hughan : l
" In 1806 Joseph Cerneau appeared in New York; he had been a
member of Masonic bodies in the West Indies ; he had a patent from
Mathieu Dupotet certifying that he had received the degrees of the
Scottish Rite of Heredom, and authorizing him to confer the degrees
up to the Twenty-fourth and organize bodies in the northern part of
Cuba, and to confer the Twenty-fifth on one <span class="t1 t8 t11 t16 t20 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">person</span> in each year, the
Twenty-fifth being then the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">highest</span> degree of the Rite and the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">highest</span> Cerneau had received, according to his patent. Cerneau had
his patent from Dupotet, who had his from Germain Hacquet, who
had his from Du Plessis, who had his from Prevost in 1790, who had
his from Francken. "2

In 1808 he <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> a grand consistory of the Rite of

" But already a controversy had arisen with parties acting
under, or deriving their powers from, the Supreme Council at
Charleston. We may <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> believe that Cerneau and his

successfully a rite of twenty-five degrees against one of
thirty-three degrees... The Thirty-third degree as now existing
originated at Charleston in 1801 ; and no evidence has been
found that Cerneau ever received it. "
Cerneau seems however to have overlooked the obvious
expedient of creating a 34th degree !
" The Charleston <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> did not recognize the Cerneau
Bodies even by silent acquiescence ; after investigation by a
special Deputy, it declared, early in 1814, Cerneau to be an
impostor, and his organizations illegal and clearly clandestine.
"
" Bitter controversies followed. " Lodges which soon died
were opened at Charleston. Others at New Orleans eked out a
precarious <span class="t11 t16 hoverable">existence</span> under James Foulhouze. " Foulhouze
had received the Thirty-third degree from the Grand Orient of
France, which expelled him, Feb. 4, 1859, for a scurrilous
publication which he issued in answer to one of its decrees.
This Supreme Council became dormant; but, in 1867, it was
revived with Eugene Chassaignac at its <span class="t7 t11 t15 t22 hoverable">head</span> ; in 1868 it was
recognized by the Grand Orient of France, and unless it has
recently gone out of existence, the Grand-Orient to-day
recognizes a so-called Supreme Council in New Orleans as a
lawful body, and its members as possessing the Thirty-third
degree ! "
In 1826 the Morgan murder occurred and Cerneau <span class="t3 t13 t18 t24 hoverable">left</span> for
France. De Witt Clinton, Governor of New York, had been
Deputy Grand Commander of the Sove-

A <span class="t3 t17 t26 hoverable">number</span> of sporadic revivals of this rite occurred during

The Hicks Rite, founded in 1832 by Comte de St. Laurent.

The Cross Body, founded about 1851 by Jeremy L. Cross.
The <span class="t2 t3 t5 t10 t12 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">Second</span> Atwood Body, founded about 1853.
It was not till 1867 that <span class="t13 hoverable">peace</span> was established between the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> de facto Supreme Councils in the northern part of the

After five <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> of peace, however, Henry J. Seymour, who

Masonic communication with the Grand Orient of France,

since but little has been <span class="t13 t14 t15 t18 t27 hoverable">heard</span> of that Supreme Council,

The Carbonari had existed internationally, it is said, under
different names since the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t6 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 hoverable">days</span> of Francis I, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> of France,
but not till the year 1815 did we begin to hear of its individual
historical achievements.
The following is a translation of one of the secret official
documents published in Italy by the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">highest</span> authority of the
order, for the guidance of the active head-centres of Masonry
in 1818, under the title of : Permanent Instructions, or
Practical Code of Rules; Guide for the Heads of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">Highest</span>
Grades of Masonry1. The original Italian document was given
to Nubio, one of the Supreme Vendita (Alta Vendita) in 1824,
when he was sent to Rome to carry it into effect, and it was to
this instruction that he referred when he wrote from Forli to
Signor Volpi : " As I have <span class="t0 t11 t24 hoverable">written</span> to you before, I am
appointed to demoralise the education of the youth of the
Church". When these documents

live. We must now consider how to reach our end, with
certainty, not cheating ourselves with delusions, which <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span>
prolong indefinitely, and probably compromise, the ultimate
success of our cause.
" Hearken not to those boastful and vainglorious French,
and thick headed Germans, and hypochondriacal Englishmen,
who seem to think it possible to end Catholicism, at one <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span>
by an obscene song, at another by an absurd sophism, and
again by a contemptible sarcasm. Catholicism has a vitality
which survives such attacks with ease. She has seen
adversaries more implacable and more terrible far, and
sometimes has <span class="t7 t10 t12 t26 hoverable">taken</span> a malicious pleasure in baptising with
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">holy</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> the most rabid amongst them. We may <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span>
allow our brethren in those countries to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> off their frenzy
of anti-catholic zeal, allow them to ridicule our Madonnas and
our apparent devotion. Under this cloak, we may conspire at
our convenience, and arrive, little by little, at our ultimate
aim.

CARBONARISM

431

" Therefore, the Papacy has been for seventeen hundred
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> interwoven with the history of Italy. Italy can neither
breathe nor move <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> the leave of the Supreme Pontiff.
With him, she has the hundred arms of Briareus ; <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> him,
she is condemned to a lamentable impotency, and to divisions
and hostility, from the foot of the Alps to the last <span class="t6 t9 t13 t15 t17 t18 t23 t28 t29 hoverable">pass</span> of the
Appen-nines. Such a <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">state</span> of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">things</span> must not remain. It is
necessary to seek a remedy. Very well. The remedy is at hand.
The Pope, whoever he may be, will never enter into a secret
society. It then becomes the duty of the Secret <span class="t1 hoverable">Society</span> to
make the first advance to the Church and to the Pope, with the
<span class="t2 hoverable">object</span> of conquering both. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> for which we gird
ourselves up, is not the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> of a day, nor of a month, nor of a
year.
" It may last for many years, perhaps for a century; in our
ranks the soldier dies, but the war is continued. We do not at
present intend to gain the Pope to our cause, nor to make him a
neophyte to our principles, or a propagator of our ideas. Such
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be an insane dream. Even should it happen that any
Cardinal, or any Prelate, of his own will, or by deception,
should share in our secrets, such <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> not be a <span class="t1 t3 t8 t25 hoverable">reason</span> for
desiring his exaltation to the Chair of Peter. Nay, his very
exaltation <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be our ruin; for this <span class="t1 t3 t8 t25 hoverable">reason</span> that, his apostasy
being prompted by his ambition alone, that very ambition of
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> necessarily impel him to <span class="t2 t9 t10 t16 t18 t19 t27 t28 hoverable">sacrifice</span> us.
" Catholics ! what must we consider Freemasonry, when
Freemasons themselves pronounce it an apostasy from
Catholicity, and foresee that a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> fully acquainted with
them and their machinations would, as a consequence, seek to
crush them.
" That which we should seek, that which we should await,
as the Jews await a Messiah, is a Pope according

to our wants. An Alexander VI <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> not suit us, for he never
erred in religious doctrine ; a Pope Borgia <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> not suit us,
for he was excommunicated by all the thinking philosophers
and unbelievers for the vigour with which he defended the
Church. We require a Pope for ourselves, if such a Pope were
possible. With such a one we should march more securely to
the storming of the Church than with all the little books of
our French and English brothers.
" And why ? Because it were useless to seek with these
alone to split the rock <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> which <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> has built his Church.
We should not want the vinegar of Hannibal, nor gunpowder,
nor even our arms, if we had but the little finger of the
successor of Peter engaged in the plot ; that little finger <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span>
avail us more for our crusade than all the Urbans II and St.
Bernards for the crusade of Christianity. We trust that we may
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> attain this supreme <span class="t2 hoverable">object</span> of our efforts.
" But when ? and how ? The unknown cannot <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> be seen.
Nevertheless, as1 nothing should move us from our
mapped-out plan, we must labour at our newly-commenced
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> as if tomorrow were to crown it with success. We wish,
in this Instruction, which should be kept concealed from those
simply initiated, to give advice to the rulers of the Supreme
Vendita, which they, in turn, should inculcate in the brethren
by means of Insegnamento, or Memorandum.
" Little can be done with old Cardinals and with prelates of
decided character. Such incorrigibles must be <span class="t3 t13 t18 t24 hoverable">left</span> to the
school of Gonsalvi, and in our magazines of popularity and
unpopularity, we must <span class="t11 t12 t22 t25 t27 hoverable">find</span> the means to utilize, or ridicule,
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> in their hands. A <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> invented report must be spread
with tact amongst <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> Christian families : such a Cardinal,
for instance, is a miser : such a prelate is licentious ; such an
official

is a freethinker, an infidel, a Freemason, and so on in the

thence to the squares, and one report is sometimes enough to

" If a prelate, or bishop, arrive in a province from Rome, to
celebrate or officiate at some public function, it is necessary
at once to become acquainted with his character, his
antecedents, his temperament, his defects — especially his

character which must horrify the young <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> and the
women ; describe him as cruel, heartless, and bloodthirsty ;
relate some atrocious transaction which will easily cause a
sensation amongst the people. The foreign newspapers will
learn and copy these facts, which they will know how to
embellish and colour according to their usual style.
" For respect due to <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">truth</span> show, or better still, quote from
some respectable fool as having quoted the <span class="t3 t17 t26 hoverable">number</span> of the
journal which has given the names, acts and doings of these
personages. As in England and in France, so also in Italy
there will be no lack of writers who <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> know how to tell lies
for the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> cause, and have no difficulty in doing so. One
newspaper publishing the name of a Monsignor Delegate, His
Excellency, or Eminence, or <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Lord</span> Justice, will be quite
sufficient proof for the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> ; they will require no other.
The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> here around us in Italy are in the infancy of
Liberalism. At present they believe in the Liberals, after a
little they will believe in anything. "
Modern Carbonarism was founded in 1815 by Maghella, a
native of Genoa, who, at the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> when Joachim Murat
became <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> Sicilies, was a subordinate of
Saliceti, the Neapolitan Minister of

Police. He was a Freemason, who exempted from initiation
and probation all Freemasons who desired to become

Masonry. 3
A sequence of events pertaining to Carbonarism can be
traced by the perusal of several <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t29 hoverable">works</span> from which we quote :
At a meeting held on Oct. 13th 1820 by the Grand Secret
Consistory, the Orient of Scotland was recognized. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span>
Consistories of Masonry in France and in Italy and that of the
Sublime Carbonari were put into communication and their
co-operation assured.4
The <span class="t23 hoverable">high</span> ruling grades of the Carbonari appear to have
been those of Sublime Maitre Parfait, above which was still
another that of the Sublime Elus. 5
The Alta Vendita constituted the Supreme Directory of the
Carbonari and was led by a group of Italian noblemen,
amongst whom a prince, " the profoundest of initiates, was
charged as Inspector General of the Order. "
Piccolo Tigre, a certain nondescript Jew, rushed about
Europe obeying orders and presumably giving them, but what
he actually did has remained a mystery.

Young Italy, Young Poland, Young England, Young

all international movements of the same character working
towards the same end, viz. the supremacy of the Masters.
The Guelphic Knights, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> <span class="t2 hoverable">object</span> was the independence

Guelphs ; but only those that had distinct offices among the
Carbonari could be admitted among the Guelphs. There can
be no doubt that the Carbonari when the sect had become very
numerous, partly sheltered themselves under the designation
of Guelphs and Adelphi or Independents, by affiliating
themselves to these societies. " 7

THE

HETAIRIA

LXVII
OF

GREECE

(ETHERISTS)

(Founded 1814)

Hetairia was the Greek name for societies, organizations or
associations. In ancient Greece the name hetairia applied to
companies in the army. In more modern times, it was <span class="t4 hoverable">used</span> for
societies of learning, or commercial purposes and also for
political secret societies.
It is in connection with the latter that we are concerned.
While Greece was under Turkish dominion, the national
aspirations of its <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> could be vented in secret only. The
breath of revolution which swept Europe during the latter part
of the 18th century stirred some of the Greek patriots <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span>
aims was the overthrow of the Turkish power. The main
leader at that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> was Constantin Rhygas (1754-1798).
He formed the first secret societies of Hetairias which
were mainly composed of Klephtes or bandits. Bound by oath,
each member of the <span class="t1 hoverable">society</span> was to <span class="t4 t18 hoverable">use</span> all means,
assassination included, to <span class="t8 t11 t14 t19 hoverable">free</span> Greece. The execution of
Rhygas drove the hetairias to seek cover but in 1814, a chief
lodge was re-formed in Odessa under the name of Hetairia
phileke. Its avowed aim was
438

THE

HETAIRIA

OF GREECE

439

the liberation of Greece, and its main seat was in Russia.
Every candidate <span class="t0 t7 t11 t13 t14 t22 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">took</span> an oath, as in all secret societies, and
knew no one beyond his initiator and sponsor. Funds,
collected and administered by a superior council directing all
the lodges, were kept in Russia.
When a sufficient <span class="t3 t17 t26 hoverable">number</span> of Hetairias were organized and
a chief needed to direct the movement against Turkey, Count
Capo d'lstria, (John, 1776-1831) a Greek, minister in Russia
under the Tzar Alexander I, and author of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">text</span> of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Holy</span>
Alliance was asked to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">take</span> the lead but refused, and
Alexander Ypsilanti was nominated. The insurrection broke
out in 1821.
Among the most prominent members of the Hetairia we
<span class="t11 t12 t22 t25 t27 hoverable">find</span> Alexander Mavrocordato (1791-1865) who was under
the influence of England and was also the friend of Byron
whom he had met in Missolonghi in 1822. From him he
received funds for the purchase of arms to the extent of one
hundred <span class="t15 t23 hoverable">thousand</span> francs. It is related that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Lord</span> Byron died in
his arms at Missolonghi in 1824. Among the supporters of the
London Branch of the Philhellenic Committee were Jeremy
Bentham, Sir Francis Burdett, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Lord</span> Erskine, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Lord</span> Ebrington,
Sir John Cam Hobhouse, (afterwards <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Lord</span> Brougham) Joseph
Hume, Sir James Mackintosh and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Lord</span> John Russell. These
foreign committees provided arms, money and volunteers.
The following details concerning the organization of the
Hetairia of Greece are <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">set</span> forth in The Secret Societies of the
European Revolution, by Thomas Frost (Vol. II, page 47 et
seq.).
" Less simple than that of the Carbonari, the system rather
resembled that of the Illuminati in the <span class="t3 t17 t26 hoverable">number</span> of grades and
relation of the branch societies to each other. "

There were five grades namely : —
The Adelphoi (Brothers, who <span class="t0 t7 t11 t13 t14 t22 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">took</span> an oath of secrecy but
ignored the aims of the society),
The Systemenoi (Bachelors, who knew that Greece was to
be freed by revolution),
The Priests of Eleusis,
The Prelates (knowing all the secrets),
The Grand Arch (The supreme directing control of 12
members).
" Early in 1827 a motion was unanimously adopted by the
Senate favouring the placing of Greece under the protection
of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Great</span> Britain. " This followed a secret interview of
Mavrocordato with Sir Stratford Canning, but Mavrocordato
retired from public <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> " on the failure of his project for the
establishment of a constitutional kingdom under British
protection."
" Hostilities in Greece were finally terminated, in the
summer of 1828, by a convention concluded at Alexandria
between Admiral Codrington and Mehemet Ali, by which the
latter agreed to withdraw the Egyptian troops from the Morea.
"
The arbitrary government of Capo d'lstria ended on
October 24, 1831, when he was assassinated.

LXVIII

THE HUNG <span class="t1 hoverable">SOCIETY</span> OF CHINA
(Founded about 1815)

This <span class="t1 hoverable">society</span> has also been known as The Triad Society,
The Ghee Hon, The <span class="t1 hoverable">Society</span> of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Heaven</span> and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Earth</span> (T'in Tei
Hui), Ts'ing-lin-Kiu, The San-ho-hoei and the Sam-ho-hui.
After the Emperor Kang Hsi issued a Sacred Edict in 1662,
ordering the suppression of Buddhism and Taoism in China,
the Hung and the White Lotus, the latter a Taoist mystical
<span class="t1 hoverable">society</span> also known by the name " White Lily ", are said to
have united to fight the Manchu Dynasty as their common
enemy.
They are supposed to have finally merged towards 1815 as
a secret political occult organization.
In 1851 the Hung broke into open revolt against the
Manchus. This is known as the Taiping Revolt and is often
alluded to as " The Triad War ". It was led by a village
schoolmaster <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> Hung who, after his defeat by Gordon in
1864, committed suicide.
Since the Taiping revolt the <span class="t1 hoverable">Society</span> has been less
conspicuous but it is supposed nevertheless to have inspired
the successful revolution which in 1911 overthrew the
Manchu Dynasty and established the Repub441

442

OCCULT THEOCRASY

lie of which Dr. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">Sun</span> Yat-Sen assumed the presidency on
January 1, 1912.
Dr. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">Sun</span> Yat-Sen, nominally a Christian, was a member of
the Hung Society, and his first official action as the first
President of the Chinese Republic was to enable Yuan Shi-Kai
to unite all parties under his presidency. He then accepted for
himself the Presidency of Nanking. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> received his
proclamation announcing these changes in front of the Ming
tombs, and listened while he told the spirits of the Mings that
the Manchu despotism, having faller, China was now a
Republic.
The Hung 1 having been outlawed since 1890 in China as a
terrorist organization, now, as a secret society, holds its
meetings in the woods at night with the approaches <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span>
guarded.
The English branch of this <span class="t1 hoverable">society</span> is at Liverpool where it
operates as a mutual benefit and charitable institution.
I, A history of the Hung is given in The Hung <span class="t1 hoverable">Society</span> by J.
S. Ward and W. G. Sterling.

historical students.

LXIX
MEMPHIS

(Founded 1815)
This rite was founded in 1815 by Sam Honis (from Cairo),
Gabriel Mathieu, Baron Dumas, Marquis de Laroque and
Hippolite Labrunie.
The Grand Lodge Osiris in Paris was founded in 1839.
Jacques Etienne Marconis was Grand Master.
In his History of Freemasonry, Freke-Gould states that " J.
E. Marconis, Grand Hierophant, inaugurated the Rite in
<span class="t1 t8 t11 t16 t20 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">person</span> at New York in 1857, and afterwards in 1862
chartered it as a Sovereign Sanctuary — by which <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> a
charter was granted on Jan. 3rd, 1872, for another Sovereign
Sanctuary in and for the British Islands <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> officers were
duly installed Oct. 8th in the same year. "
The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span> is now known in England as " The Ancient and
Primitive Rite. "
On December 30, 1862, the rite of Memphis merged finally
into the Grand Orient of France and in England, in 1875 under
the name of Ancient and Primitive Rite, it amalgamated with
that oi Mizraim which Gould informs us had no separate
governing <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> in chat country.
In 1865, the Grand Orient reduced the original 97 degrees
to 33.
