CALDERARI

(Founded 1816)

The Calderari del Contrapeso, an offshoot of the Carbonari,
came into prominence about 1816.
Their first organizer, The Prince of Canosa, became
Minister of Police under Ferdinand, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> of Naples, in
December, 1819.
The Calderari were the sworn enemies of the Freemasons
and Carbonari.
They <span class="t0 t7 t11 t13 t14 t22 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">took</span> the following oath : —
" I, N. N., promise and swear <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the Trinity, as supreme
director of the universe, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> this cross, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> this steel,
the avenging instrument of the perjured— to live and die in
the Roman Catholic and Apostolic faith, and to defend with
my blood this religion, and the <span class="t1 hoverable">society</span> of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">True</span> Friendship, the
Calderari, to which I am about to belong. I swear never to
offend, in honour, life, or property, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">children</span> of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">True</span>
Friendship ; I promise and swear to all the Knights, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span>
friends, all possible succour that shall depend on me. I swear
to initiate no <span class="t1 t8 t11 t16 t20 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">person</span> into the <span class="t1 hoverable">Society</span> before I arrive at the 4th

LXXI

CARBONARISM

(Founded 1820)
The Masonic Lodge Les Amis de la Verite was founded in
1820 by Buchez, Flotard, Bazard and Jou-bert, all
Freemasons, for political purposes. On a riot incited by
members of this lodge a young <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> was killed. As a
consequence of his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> this lodge <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">went</span> out of existence.
One of its former members, Dugied, a Freemason, was
initiated into the mysteries of Carbonarism while at Naples. 1
Having conceived the project of introducing this association
into France he discussed the <span class="t25 hoverable">matter</span> with another ex-member
of the Ami's de la Verite, Flotard, and <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t9 t11 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">together</span> they decided
to put the idea into practice by taking as a nucleus of the new
organization the remains of Les Amis de la Verite.
The <span class="t1 hoverable">society</span> was organized as follows :—
The one " Haute Vente ", central " Ventes " and individual
" Ventes " (lodges).
The "Haute Vente" was the committee of direction and
action. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Two</span> members of the committee having found an
adept, the adept <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> agree with them to

<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">form</span> a " Vente ". The adept <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> become President one of
the others censor, the other deputy, the role of the last being to
keep in touch with the committee while allowing the

These <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> chiefs were

what had been made above them, forming an individual "
Vente " of the first order, which, repeating the same process
formed an ordinary individual " Vente " <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> extending
indefinitely the ramifications of the sect.
A similar organization, but under different names, was
adapted to the army. There the Haute Vente was <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> the
Legion, the central Ventes, the Cohortes, the individual
Ventes of the first <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span> the Centuries ; and the ordinary
individual Ventes the Manipules.
This double system was intended to puzzle the police, by
making it believe that there was a separate association in the
army. A further measure of precaution forbade a Carbonaro,
under penalty of death, being affiliated to another Vente. This
precaution was intended to prevent anyone entering different
groups and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> possibly discovering and denouncing the
seerets of the society.
The direction of the Ventes was indeed centralized but this
unity of control was to be ignored by most of the members.
The Carbonari had no settled principles. It accepted all
opinions provided these favoured the elimination of royal
families. The imperialists and liberals formed important
nuclei. The latter, the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t6 t7 t13 t14 t15 t20 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">sons</span> of middle-class

FRENCH CARBONARISM

449

parents, stirred against the government by patriotism, youth
and class jealousy, dreamed only of grabbing the influence of
the old families. As for what is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> the people, it did not
count in Carbonarism ; the illustrious role attributed to it later
had not <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> been invented !
To begin with, the Haute Yente counted only seven
members : Dugied, Flotard, Bazard, Buchez, Joubert, Carriol,
Limperani. Among them we <span class="t11 t12 t22 t25 t27 hoverable">find</span> again the four heads of the
Amis de la Verite.
The Carbonari having prospered, the Haute Vente found it
advisable to annex some notable characters. Among others,
the Freemason General Lafayette, who, even in old age, had a
childish weakness for popularity, accepted the offer to join
the conspiracy.
Towards the end of 1820 the <span class="t1 hoverable">society</span> had many branches,
notably those of Bordeaux, Nantes, Toulouse, La Bochelle,
Poitiers, Colmar, Belfort, etc.
The subversive efforts of this <span class="t1 hoverable">society</span> culminated in an
abortive attempt at Bevolution at La Bochelle, and the
subsequent arrest of many of its principal members
completed its nominal dissolution.
After the debacle at La Rochelle the Amis de la Verite
merged into the Amis du Peuple which in turn, in 1832,
became the Droits de I'Homme. After its unsuccessful
attempt to assassinate the king, (Louis Philippe) in 1835 the
remains of the Droits de I'Homme reorganized as the Societe
des Families with Blanqui and Barbes as leaders. According
to Lucien de la Hodde,2 Carbonarism in France had ceased to
exist by 1822, except for a few obstinates like Charles Teste,
(a friend of Babeuf) and Buonarotti who remained
2. Lucien de la Hodde, Histoire des Societes Secretes.

450

THEOCRASY

faithful to the old organization. Lucien de la Hodde however,
while following Carbonarism, lost sight of the Haute Vente
which, working through Mazzini and the International
Committee of London, directed its <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> of destruction in
France through Ledru Rollin and Felix Pyat. After its collapse
in 1836 the Societe des Families became that of the Saisons
(seasons) and it was a branch of this society, the Societe dissidents, that served the purpose of the Haute Vente in 1848 by
aiding in the terrorisation of Paris and the fall of the
Monarchy.
The self-appointed members of the provisional government of France after the abdication of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">king</span> were : —
Dupont (de l'Eure) Member of the original Carbonari
founded in 1820, Arago, Lamartine, Ledru Rollin,
Garnier-Pages, Marie, Cremieux.
Lucien de la Hodde was the agent of the French Secret
Police, and for 8 <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> before the revolution of 1848
occupied an exalted position in the ranks of the
Revolutionaries.
His conclusions are strangely at variance with the facts
which he relates. On page 381, he tells how an indiscretion on
the part of Caussidiere, one of his associates, placed the
blame of a conspiracy <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> Ledru Rollin and, because Ledru
Rollin calmly denied <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> of the affair, de la Hodde
accepts his statement <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> question.
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Though</span> a bona-fide student of the subject, it is quite
evident that de la Hodde had failed to grasp the principle
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> which Revolutionary organizations operate, <span class="t5 t10 hoverable">viz</span> : that of
a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> of dupes <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> particular job is genuinely to believe
that their organization is the executive one. Into this one all

MODERN KNIGHTS TEMPLAR
POLAND
(Founded 1822)
Heckethorn1 tells us of a sect which arose in Poland in
1818 which he refers to as that of " National Freemasonry ",
which borrowed the rites, degrees, and language of
Freemasonry, but aimed at national independence. The
<span class="t1 hoverable">society</span> was open to persons of all classes, but sought chiefly
to enlist soldiers and officials, so as to turn their technical
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> to <span class="t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">account</span> in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> of the struggle. But <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span>
numerous, the <span class="t1 hoverable">society</span> lasted only a few <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> : for disunion
arose among the members, and it escaped total dissolution
only by transformation. It altered its rites and ceremonies,
and henceforth <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> itself the " Scythers ", in remembrance
of the revolution of 1794, in which <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> regiments, armed
with scythes, had gone into battle.
They met in 1821 at Warsaw, and drew up a new
revolutionary scheme, adopting at the same <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> the new
denomination of " Patriotic Society". In the
1. Heckethorn. Secret Societies of All Ages and Countries, vol.
II, p. 175.

meanwhile, the students of the university of Wilna had

Simon Konarski (1808-1839) was a young Polish patriot

travelled to France, England and Belgium and, in the latter
country, namely in Brussels, was in constant touch with
Lelewel who had been chosen by Mazzini to become the link

Young Poland
movement
was
directed
by
Zwierkowsky.
Simon Konarski was seized by the Russian authorities and

CHAPTER

LXXIV

BRAHMO

SOMAJ

(Founded 1830)

The Brahmo Somaj movement, also <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> Brah-moism or
Brahmaism, was founded by Rajah Ram Mohun Roy
(1774-1833), in 1830.
Its main <span class="t2 hoverable">object</span> was to fight idolatrous rites and practices,
and, by many, it has been described as a " Hindu Unitarian
Church. "
The chief achievement of Ram Mohun Roy was the
abolition by <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Lord</span> William Bentinck of the practice of " suttee
" (sacrifice of the widow on the funeral pyre of her husband).
Ram Mohun Roy's principles were Theistic. He had also
for several <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> studied Lamaism in the Himalayas. Having
come to England in 1830, he was received with much honour
by many sections of <span class="t1 hoverable">society</span> and entertained by Louis Philippe.
He was considered a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> authority by all those who at that
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> were conducting spiritualist and psychic researches. He
died at Bristol.
A <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> impulse was given to the Brahmo Somaj by
Debendra Nath Tagore (also <span class="t0 t11 t24 hoverable">written</span> Devendranath Takur)
who had joined it in 1842 and is considered as its <span class="t2 t3 t5 t10 t12 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">second</span>
founder.
455

456

OCCULT THEOCRASY

Owing to his efforts, the institution became purely Theistic,
giving up the authority of the Yedas and eliminating the
Vedantic element from the Brahmic covenant. In 1856,
Debendra Nath Tagore had also gone to the Himalayas where
he spent <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> as a disciple of the Tibetan Lamas. Later,
he was joined in his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> by his friend Keshub Chunder Sen
who, however, in 1863, devoured by the ambition of
becoming sole leader, attacked the Somaj, heading what one
might <span class="t3 t11 t18 t27 hoverable">call</span> the revolt of the " Young Brah-maists " and with
his followers seceded from the Mother organization.
The schism gave rise to the formation of another Somaj
which was directed by Keshub Chunder Sen under the name
Somaj of India, whereas the former organization, remaining
under the leadership of Debendra Nath Tagore, was <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span>
Adi Samaj or Original Church. It was also named "
Conservative ", in opposition to the new institution termed "
Progressive ".
Keshub Chunder Sen retained <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> in his organization ;
the foundation stone of the Somaj of India Church was laid at
Jhamapukur in Calcutta, in 1868. In 1870 he journeyed to
England where he was enthusiastically received by the
spiritualist centres of the day, and succeeded in exciting much
interest in the political, social and religious affairs of India. In
1878, his disregard for the rules of the Somaj regarding
Hindu marriages which he infringed in the <span class="t25 hoverable">matter</span> of the
wedding of his own daughter to the young Maharajah of
Kuch Behar, caused another split in the ranks of the Somaj of
India. The dissidents then formed the Sadharan Brahmo
Somaj.
The career of Keshub Chunder Sen must be followed with
interest by students of Theosophy. Therein will they <span class="t11 t12 t22 t25 t27 hoverable">find</span>
many of the odd principles and injunctions

BRAHMO

SOMAJ

457

laid down by H. P. Blavatsky and Annie Besant. For instance,
the theocratic system was that promoted by Keshub Chunder
Sen in his efforts to found a universal religion which <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span>
unite all creeds and symbols ; the Christian Cross, the
Crescent, the Vedic Om, the Saiva's trident and the
Vaishnava's Khunti. By means of imaginary pilgrimages, he
led his adherents successively to the shrines of Moses,
Buddha, to the Himalayan heights and Lama teachers, to
<span class="t0 t6 t8 t9 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t22 t23 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Jesus</span> and to Mahomet.
Similarly to Annie Besant's Khrishnamurti, he allowed
himself to be worshipped as the Saviour of Sinners ; his
theory was the reincarnation of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Great</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Men</span> of which he was
one. Further, he complacently allowed his followers to raise
him to the dignity of a deity. As the Kheshub Chunder Sen's
worship increased, there grew also the dogma of <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Divine</span>
Injunction. A salient feature of Keshub's teaching was the
belief or blind <span class="t4 t7 t12 t16 hoverable">faith</span> in the revelations claimed to have been
made to invisible teachers and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> guides and exaction
of blind obedience to their commands. We are forcibly
reminded of the claim made by H. P. Blavatsky to her
followers to sign their blind acceptance of all orders
presumably received from invisible masters like her Koot
Hoomi.
Another feature which, later, distinguished Keshub
Chunder Sen's devotees was the " Bhakti " <span class="t6 hoverable">side</span> of their
religion. Unlike " Yoga ", the old Hindu type of religious
<span class="t25 hoverable">meditation</span> or contemplation, " Bhakti ", which has been
chiefly developed by the followers of Chay-tania in India, is a
manifestation of religious frenzy. It spurns the aspiration to
approach <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> by concentration of <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">thought</span> and <span class="t3 t8 t9 t10 t11 t18 t19 t20 hoverable">desire</span> as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span>
as silent communion, which they deem unprofitable and vain.
The philosophy of " Bhakti " is that the <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t8 t13 t15 t17 t18 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">love</span> of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> must

458

OCCULT THEOCRASY

be strong to the point of being maddening. It <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span>
induces dancing, sobbing, swooning. The more frenzied the
manifestations, the greater the religious perfection. A <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span>
Bhakta is one who, like the founder of the school, shows the
greatest religious madness.
Women devotees of Keshub Chunder Sen's following were
formed into a sisterhood in 1881 and one hears of " ladies'
journies to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Spirit</span> <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">land</span> ". The readers of " Inquire <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">Within</span> "
1
will remember the description of " journeys in the Astral "
claimed to have been accomplished by women adepts of the

were likewise formed into a brotherhood and were initiated
into different <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">holy</span> orders. In both cases, the <span class="t3 t17 t26 hoverable">number</span> of

Horn, Sacred <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Fire</span> or Blazing Agni. Most of the rites are

named Kundalini.
In 1880, Keshub Chunder Sen had given his organization
another name, that of " The New Dispensation ".
It is in the Societas Rosicruciana in Anglia that one must
seek the amalgamation of Jewish Cabala magic and Hindu
magic. The latter swept over Europe with the spread of
Theosophy and flourished particularly in England. There it
had found a ground in 1830 with the teachings given by Ram
Mohun Roy to the spiritualists of that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> with whom he had
formed a Brahmo Somaj circle.

CHAPTER

LXXV

THE MORMONS
(Founded 1830)

Soon after the establishment of Mormonism its founder,
Joseph Smith, conceived the idea of establishing a Masonic
super rite.
In M. R. Werner's <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">book</span> Brigham Young (page 62) the
following remark makes this evident.
" Masonry was always popular with the Mormons until
Joseph Smith claimed that an angel of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Lord</span> had <span class="t0 t4 t6 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t19 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">brought</span>
him the lost key-words of several degrees, enabling him to
progress further than the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">highest</span> Masons. The charter of the
Mormon lodge was then <span class="t7 t10 t12 t26 hoverable">taken</span> away by the Grand Lodge ".
Joseph Smith, applying his powers of mediumship towards
the realization of the ambitious project nurtured by General
Pepe, Mazzini and others for the establishment of a super rite,
was not necessarily acceptable to the Masonic leaders of his
time.
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Thus</span> as a Mason he failed but as the founder of a Masonic
sect he succeeded.
So much has already been <span class="t0 t11 t24 hoverable">written</span> about the sect of the
Mormons that we confine ourselves here to a short sketch of
opinion and descriptions given by various authors. The
following is extracted from The Encyclopaedia Britannica,
9th Edition.
459

460

OCCULT THEOCRASY

" This is a religious non-Christian sect, founded by Joseph
Smith at Manchester, New York, in 1830, now settled in Salt
Lake City, Territory of Utah, United States... Smith was <span class="t16 t24 hoverable">born</span>
Dec. 23rd, 1805, at Sharon, Windsor County, Vermont, from
which <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> ten <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> later his parents, a poor, ignorant,
thriftless, and not too honest couple, removed to New York,
where they settled on a small farm near Palmyra, Wayne
County (then Ontario). Four <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> later, in 1809, they
removed to Manchester, some six miles off; and it was at the
latter <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> when fifteen <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> old that Joseph began to have
his alleged visions, in one of which on the night of 21st Sept.,
1823, the angel Moroni appeared to him <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> times, and told
him that the Bible of the Western Continent, the supplement
to the New Testament, was buried in a certain spot near
Manchester. Thither, four <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> later and after due

Smith and his followers founded the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">city</span> of Nauvoo and "

He organized a military <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> the Nauvoo legion, of
which he constituted himself commander with the title of
lieutenant-general, while he was also president of the church
and mayor of the city. On April 6th, 1841, the foundations of
the new temple were laid, and the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">city</span> continued to grow
rapidly in prosperity and size. "
Smith's career of treason, profligacy, dishonesty,
polygamy, spiritism and humbug, came to an abrupt end
when the gaol in which he was imprisoned by <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span> of the
Governor of the <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">State</span> was broken into by a mob who shot him
and his fellow prisoner, his brother Hyram.
As <span class="t7 t11 t15 t22 hoverable">head</span> of the Mormons he was succeeded by Brigham
Young (1801-1877).
In 1846, the repeal by the legislature of the charter of
Nauvoo resulted in the Mormons being driven from the city.
In March 1849, they held a convention at Salt Lake City,
and a <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">State</span> was organized under the name of " Deseret ". "A
legislature was elected and a constitution framed, which was
sent on to Washington. This, Congress refused to recognize,
and by <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> of compromise for declining to admit the
proposed new <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">State</span>

The following description of a Mormon ceremony was
printed in the Rosicrucian in an article entitled " Ancient and
Modern Mysteries " by M. W. Frater Robert Wentworth Little
(page 169).
" The converts are then required to purchase white linen
garments, which are furnished by the ' <span class="t23 hoverable">high</span> deacon '. They are
then conducted to the temple, ushered into a private room, and
commanded to undress for the inspection of the presiding
elder '. This official, after a minute examination, clothes the
neophytes in the linen robes or garments of endowment and
conducts them into a large room which is divided by white
screens into many small compartments. Each neophyte enters
one of the compartments, and is ordered to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">take</span> off the '
endowment robe ' and to step into a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> coffin-shaped tin
bath. The elder then pours <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the naked victim —
blessing each member of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> as the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> touches it — '
the brain to be clear and strong — the <span class="t2 t7 t13 t14 t18 t22 t23 t24 hoverable">eyes</span> to be bright and
sharp — the ears to be quick to hear ', and so on down to the
feet — this ceremony being performed <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> all, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span>
distinction of sex. A new name is then given to each convert
by the elder, who commands them to ' arise and follow me '. A
magnificent garden, <span class="t5 hoverable">full</span> of exquisite fruit-trees, is the scene
of the next ceremony. The candidates are still in a <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">state</span> of
nudity, which represents primeval

progressive universal religion while seeking to unite in itself

I. O. B. B. (JEWISH MASONRY)

(Founded 1843)

B'nai B'rith means " <span class="t0 t2 t3 t6 t7 t13 t14 t15 t20 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Sons</span> of the Covenant ", the Covenant
being that of circumcision practised according to the Mosaic
law. Hence the Independent <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">Order</span> of the B'nai B'rith admits
only Jews as members.
This rite "was founded in New York in 1843 by a <span class="t3 t17 t26 hoverable">number</span>
of German Jews, headed by Henry Jones. " l
Its constitution, District Lodges, Grand Lodges, stamp it
as a Jewish Masonic Society.
Like most societies, it covers its political activities under
the cloak of " benevolence and philanthropy. "
From its inception until the present time, its main contact
has been with Germany and its chief aim the establishment of
the supremacy of the German Jews in all <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> affairs
through the channel of " Internationalism".
In 1882, the strength of the I. 0. B. B. in the United States
warranted the opening of Lodges in Germany by Moritz
Ettinger, and the growth of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span> was s6 rapid there that
in 1885, Julius Bien, President of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">Order</span> in New York,

YOUNG IRELAND
(Founded 1843)

Captain H. B. C. Pollard, in writing of the Young Ireland
movement says " The leaders of the Young Ireland Party of
1848 were John Mitchell, an advanced Radical, deeply tinged
with Jacobin ideas, and William Smith O'Brien, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span>
brother later became <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Lord</span> Inchiquin. They obtained popular
support by <span class="t1 t3 t8 t25 hoverable">reason</span> of the widespread misery caused by the
Potato famine of ' Black Forty-seven. ' Gavan Duffy, Dillon,
Doheny, O'Gorman and Stephens were all minor conspirators.
Mitchell and O'Brien were transported to Van Diemens Land,
but the younger <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> mostly made <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> their escape and lived
in exile in Paris and America. " '
" The old traditional combination of an open movement

habits was revived in 1850, when the Tenant Defence <span class="t1 hoverable">Society</span>
was founded with the <span class="t2 hoverable">object</span> of enforcing, by agitation,
legislation which was to accomplish by legal means that
expropriation of property that the combined genius of

" There was no formal excommunication, but a quiet <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span>
firm ban was placed on the party. " 4
The Young Ireland Movement was but a branch of the Young
Europe Movement led by Mazzini, the main history of which will

THE BAHAI MOVEMENT
(Founded 1844)

" Inquire Within", in her <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">book</span> Light-bearers of Darkness,
gives an excellent summary of the crigin and scope of this sect.
From her <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> we quote the following :
" This movement was founded in 1844 by a Persian, Mirza
Ali Muhammad, who <span class="t0 t7 t11 t13 t14 t22 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">took</span> the title of ' Bab ' (the Gate); he
revolted against the Hierarchy, who, fearing his growing
influence, had him shot at Tabriz, 1850.
" It claims to be the fulfilment ' of that which was but
partially revealed in previous dispensations ', and they look
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> Buddha, Zoroaster, Jesus, Mohammed, and Confucius
as merely preparing the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> for the advent of the ' Most
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Great</span> <span class="t13 hoverable">Peace</span> ' and the ' Mighty <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">World</span> Educator ' Baha'u'llah
(Glory of God), 1863-92, and later Abdul-Baha, 1892-1921.
It further claims to be the unity of all religions, also older and
modern movements, such as Theosophy, Freemasonry,
Spiritualism, Socialism, etc. ; it aims at conferring illumination <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> humanity, and like all illuminated groups, it <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t29 hoverable">works</span>
for universal peace, religion, education, language (Esperanto),
and universal everything leading to unity of humanity;
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span> all prejudices must be abandoned,

470

OCCULT THEOCRASY

traditional, racial, patriotic, religious and political ; all
religions must be in accordance with science and reason. "
The Bahais have a temple in Chicago, the building of
which was begun in 1903 which " Inquire <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">Within</span> " describes
as being a perfect nonagon in form, all its dimensions being
based on the <span class="t3 t17 t26 hoverable">number</span> nine, " the cabalistic <span class="t3 t17 t26 hoverable">number</span> of
generation, which initiates and leads to unity with the
universal astral light. " 1
The same author further explains the organization of the
sect most concisely in the following lines :
" There is a Guardian of the Cause — Shogi-Effendi —
with nine co-workers, and in each town there is a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t29 hoverable">Spiritual</span>
Assembly of nine members, who must be consulted, absolutely obeyed, and submitted to. There are also National
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t29 hoverable">Spiritual</span> Assemblies in all countries to which the cause has
spread, and, finally, they are making elaborate plans to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">form</span>
an International <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t29 hoverable">Spiritual</span> Assembly to be elected by all
believers — to enact ordinances and regulations not found in
the explicit <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Holy</span> Text. "
We leave it to anyone interested to follow the subversive
activities of this sect in either the political or religious realm.

" In 1819, Thomas Wildey established in Baltimore the
first lodge of Oddfellows in the United States, and from 1825
till 1833, he was Grand Sire of the Grand Lodge.
" In 1843 Grand Sire Howell Hopkins of Pennsylvania was
installed, and the United States Grand Lodge issued a
dispensation for opening the Prince of Wales Lodge No. 1 at
Montreal, Canada.
" In 1844 The Grand Lodge (Oddfellows U. S. A.)
appointed a Ritual Revision Committee and entirely changed
all the working, rejecting the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> of the English work, and

LXXX

MODERN SPIRITISM
(Founded 1848)

Modern Spiritism, sometimes <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> Spiritualism, traces its
descent from the mystifications of Catherine and Margaret
Fox, the daughters of John Fox, who, in 1848, during the
course of experiments conducted in a haunted <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">house</span> at
Hydesville, New York, U. S. A. elaborated a system of
communication by raps, with invisible entities. Both sisters
eventually confessed to having abused the credulity of the
public in their spiritist seances but the universal interest
aroused by the phenomena at Hydesville did not abate.
Since then, there has been a regular epidemic of table
turning, ouija boards, planchettes, automatic writings and
similar modes, more or less effective, for achieving
mediumship.
The acquisition of this type of mediumship exposes the
aspirant to the danger of an induced <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">state</span> of mental passivity
during which the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> may register vibrations broadcast
from some terrestrial centre such as that provided by the
recently constituted " Polaire <span class="t1 hoverable">Society</span> " and recognized by the
H. B. of L. (See page 531).
The cultivation of spiritism under all its different aspects
either for amusement or pseudo-scientific inves473

drain their vital energy to such an extent that, when such

of obsession. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">People</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> psychic experiments have

mediumship has been achieved the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> is open for such

priests as lunacy, possession, obsession, alternating
personality and sadism.
Mediumship does not imply power. A medium is a
receiver and, as such, furthers the will of another. The fakirs
of India are mediums.
That these phenomena are real has been proved by such
prominent scientists as Crooks, Richet and Flam-marion and
the mediumistic exploits of such persons as D. I). Home are
so <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> known and attested that we will give but one short
extract here from page 171 of The Rosicrucian, quoting a
speech by <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Lord</span> Lindsay, Senior Grand Warden of England,
for the benefit of persons who may happen to have no
acquaintance with the subject.
" I may mention that on another occasion I was sitting with
Mr. Home and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Lord</span> Adare and a cousin of his. During the

following. The comment concerns John Wilkes <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> "

Wilkes contrived to let a baboon loose <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> one of the

those who, being victims of their own greed, are amenable to

LICENSED

CLAIRVOYANTS

In the bill now before Parliament it is
proposed that spiritualists shall be given
immunity from prosecution, provided that there
is no i n t e n t i o n to defraud. The following are
specifically mentioned as coming <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">within</span> the
scope of the bill :
Promoter, chairman, or other official,
Lecturer or speaker,
Clairvoyant,
Medium.
For the purposes of the bill, " medium " and "
clairvoyant " are defined as <span class="t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t18 t19 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">meaning</span> a <span class="t1 t8 t11 t16 t20 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">person</span> "
holding a certificate or licence of fitness to
p r a c t i s e either as a medium or clairvoyant, or
in both c a p a c i t i e s , such certificate or licence
to be i s s u e d by registered or properly
constituted
spiritualistic
or
psychical
societies, or a j o i n t committee representing
such societies, or such other certifying or
l i c e n s i n g <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> as may be approved by one of
his Majesty's Principal Secretaries of State.

SPIRITISM

The Societies of Psychical Research, both in England and
America, exist today as scientific centres for information and
investigation of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> phenomena. Persons interested in these
" mysteries " <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> do <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> to avail themselves of their
protection and the facilities they afford for serious work. The
English <span class="t1 hoverable">Society</span> was founded in 1882 by Henry Sidgwick,
Edmund Gurney, Frederick Meyers, W. T. Barrett and others.
For root of this movement see <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">Chapter</span> XXII. For
development of this movement see Chapters CVIII, CIX,

THE IRISH REPUBLICAN BROTHERHOOD (I. R
B.)
THE FENIANS.

(Founded 1857-1858)
Concerning this famous Secret Society, Captain Pollard
writes :
" From its earliest <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t6 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 hoverable">days</span> to the present <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> the I. R. B. has
existed as a militant revolutionary secret society, with the
avowed <span class="t2 hoverable">object</span> of separating Ireland from all connection with
the British Empire and establishing an independent
Republican Government. l
" The founders of this movement were Colonel John
O'Mahoney and a barrister, Michael Doheney, both of whom
had fled from Ireland for their share in the rising of 1848.
Both these <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> <span class="t0 t7 t11 t13 t14 t22 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">took</span> refuge in France, at that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> a hot-bed
of secret Carbonarist societies, such as the Communistes
Revolulionnaires, the Constitutional <span class="t1 hoverable">Society</span> with its ' Acting
Company ', the Seasons and many others, and it was in Paris
that these <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> fugitives lived with James Stephens, the real
<span class="t7 t11 t15 t22 hoverable">head</span> and organizer of the Fenian movement, who was also a
refugee. "
" In 1857 a messenger was sent from New York to James
Stephens, then in Dublin, asking him to get

up an organization in Ireland on resources provided from the
States (U. S. A.) ; and it is clear that Stephens had already
cut-and-dried plans in his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> as to how this was to be done.
He stated his terms, which were agreed to, and on St. Patrick's
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Day</span> 1858, the I. R. B. movement was initiated by Stephens
and Luby in Dublin. "
In 1859 the I. R. B. exacted the following oath ; " I, A. B.,
in the presence of Almighty God, do solemnly swear
allegiance to the Irish Republic now virtually established ;
and that I will do my utmost, at every risk, while <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> lasts, to
defend its independence and integrity ; and finally that I will
yield implicit obedience in all things, not contrary to the laws
of God, to the commands of my superior officers. So help me
God. Amen. "
" The organization made rapid headway, but the weight of
the Roman Catholic Hierarchy was surging against the
movement, and in due course the Brotherhood was
excommunicated ; in 1861 no Fenian could get absolution. "
In reference to the founding of the Fenian <span class="t1 hoverable">society</span> in
America, Heckethorn fifty <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> ago had <span class="t0 t11 t24 hoverable">written</span> the
following :
" In Nov. 1863, the Fenian organization assumed a new
character. A grand national convention of delegates met at
Chicago and avowed the <span class="t2 hoverable">object</span> of the Brotherhood, namely,
the separation of Ireland from England, and the establishment
of an Irish republic, the same changes being first to be
effected in Canada. Another grand convention was held in
1864 at Cincinnati, the delegates at which represented some
250,000 members, each of which members was <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span>
for a contribution of five dollars, and this call, it is said, was
promptly responded to.... About the same <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> a Fenian
Sisterhood was established, and the

ladies were not inactive ; for in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> months from their

To raise money the Fenians issued bonds redeemable 90

Availing ourselves of the remarkable documentation
furnished by Captain Pollard we gather the following facts :
" The American Fenian Brotherhood was a separate
organization, distinct from the Irish Fenian Brotherhood or I.
R. B. having its own leaders ; but both organizations were on
the same lines and had their officers, both civil and military
oaths, emblems, and passwords, funds and stores of arms. " 3
All was <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> till Sept. 14, 1865 when "the Dublin
authorities, who were thoroughly <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> informed, raided the
offices of The Irish <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">People</span> and arrested the staff.
James Stephens was arrested with the rest but " escaped
through the nominal complicity of a warder, John Breslin,
who was also a member of the I. R. B. "
" Stephens had received some twenty-five <span class="t15 t23 hoverable">thousand</span>
pounds, little of which was spent in Ireland, and in later <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span>
it was a <span class="t25 hoverable">matter</span> of common <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> that Stephens, besides
being <span class="t7 t11 t15 t22 hoverable">Head</span> Centre, had also an agreement with the British
Government, which threw a peculiar <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> on his immunity
from arrest and his later escape from prison and leisurely
retreat to France. "4
On March 5, 1867, " Colonel " Kelly, heading a dissident
group of Fenians, established a Directory

separate from the original I. R. B. in London.
" Kelly, it should be noted, was the inventor of the

' treason ' to the Brotherhood. "
" In 1869 new influences in America and Paris succeeded
in reforming the I. R. B. Directorate in London, a nd the
organization became not only a mainspring of revolutionary
endeavour in Ireland, but a definite element in the complex
machinery of world-revolution. "
In March 1865, the Fenians joined the amalgamation of
subversive Secret Societies under Karl Marx, known as the
International Association of Working Men, founded in
London on September 28th.
" It is, at all events, clear that Marx and the leaders of the I.
R. B. were in close touch, and that Marx knew, even if the
mass of Irish dupes did not, that the Irish revolutionary dream
of the I. R. B. and Fenian leaders was no merely nationalist
rebellion, but was to be a social revolution.5
" The function of the Fenian ' General ' Cluseret and his
relation to the International are not precisely clear, but he
appears to have acted as a chief of the military rather than the
civil <span class="t6 hoverable">side</span> of the secret Lodges. During his stay in England on
his Fenian mission he paid particular attention to the problem
of how London might be captured, held and burnt.... After the
suppression of the Paris branch of the Internationale it was
Cluseret who organized the workers as a secret communist
revolutionary society. "
The more recent activities of the I. R. B. should be
followed in connection with The Clan-na-Gael.

LXXXIII

PHOENIX <span class="t1 hoverable">SOCIETY</span> OF SKIBBEREEN
(Founded 1858)
In our enumeration of subversive societies we must
include the Phoenix <span class="t1 hoverable">Society</span> of Skibbereen of which Captain
Pollard writes the following in The Secret Societies of
Ireland (page 46).
" In 1858 a premature organization, contrived to revive the
tenets of the Young Irishmen of ten <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> earlier, was
founded at Skibbereen by Jeremiah O'Dono-van Rossa and
James Stephens. Both these <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> were later to attain notoriety
in criminal annals, but the Phoenix <span class="t1 hoverable">Society</span> was abortive.
Attacked by the priests it was suppressed. "
This <span class="t1 hoverable">society</span> is interesting to us on <span class="t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">account</span> of the
subsequent career of James Stephens, one of its founders,
who had previously been identified with the Fenian
movement.
For root of this movement see <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">Chapter</span> LXXXII.

LXXXIV

L'ALLIANCE ISRAELITE UNIVERSELLE
(A BRANCH

OF JEWISH

MASONRY)

(Founded 1860)
If, as it has been appropriately defined, Judaism is a sect,
the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t9 t12 t15 t16 t17 t19 t22 t24 t25 t26 hoverable">creation</span> of the Alliance Israelite Univer-selle which <span class="t0 t7 t11 t13 t14 t22 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">took</span>
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> in 1860 can be regarded as that of its exoteric centre.
It was founded in 1860 by Aristide Astruc, Isidor Cahen,
Jules Carvalho, Narcisse Leven, Eugene Manuel and Charles
Netter. Its first president was Konigs-warter. Adolphe
Cremieux was president from 1863-1867 and again from
1868-1880.
In 1840, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> had been startled by the news of the
fearful murder of Pere Thomas at Damascus. Serious
investigations had resulted in the conviction of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> Jews
who had confessed to the commission of the abominable
crime for Jewish ritual purposes of procuring <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span> blood.
The indignation of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> rising against Jewry
made its prominent members realise the danger threatening
their newly acquired emancipation in most countries, and they
made a concerted effort to disprove Jewish guilt in the
Damascus affair. Foremost among them had been <span class="t15 t23 hoverable">Moses</span>
Monte fiore, Adolphe Cremieux
486

L'ALLIANCE ISRAELITE UNIVERSELLE

4 87

and Solomon Munk. Yet, the real inspirer of the Alliance
Israelite Universelle was Hirsch Kalisher, Rabbi of Thorn
(Russia) and its enthusiastic exponent, <span class="t15 t23 hoverable">Moses</span> Hess.
The chief aim of the Alliance Israelite Universelle was
political, and was clearly expressed in the report circulated
after its foundation in which was stated : All important faiths
are represented in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> by nations, that is to say, they are
incarnated in governments especially interested in them and
officially authorized to represent them and <span class="t9 t11 t20 t21 t22 t23 t27 hoverable">speak</span> for them
only. Our <span class="t4 t7 t12 t16 hoverable">faith</span> alone is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> this important advantage; it is
represented neither by a <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">state</span> nor by a society, nor does it
occupy a clearly defined territory.
The Alliance Israelite Universelle <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span> was destined to
be the governmental representative of all Jews from whatever
country they lived in under the authority of their secret Kahal
or community rule.
The first political manifestation of the Alliance Israelite
Universelle <span class="t0 t7 t11 t13 t14 t22 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">took</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> at the Berlin Congress in 1878 where it
was represented by <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> of its delegates : Kann, Netter and
Veneziani.
The link between the Alliance Israelite Universelle and
Freemasonry was for many <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> Adolphe Cre-mieux and
Masonic writers have asserted that the 18th degree, conferreo
by the Grand Orient, makes the initiate, if not a member, at
any rate a supporter of the Alliance.
The Alliance Israelite Universelle saw its dream of
international Jewish Government shattered when Zionism
emerged and came tc the fore in 1897. It is noteworthy that
the " Prophet " of Zionism : Ahad Ha'am (Asher Ginsberg)
was a member of the Alliance Israelite Universelle and a
disciple of Charles Netter. The avowed

(Founded 1860)

In his early days, Karl Marx, later to be the moving <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> of
the First International, edited a paper in Paris, Annates
Franco-Allemandes, the organ of a secret society. This paper
had been founded by Arnold Riige, a disciple of Mazzini.
Marx met Riige through Henri Heine, the celebrated poet. l
Heckethorn, in his Secret Societies of All Ages and
Countries gives an interesting synopsis of the early phases of
this movement destined ultimately to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">form</span> the keystone of
subversion throughout the world. 2
" The first attempt at an international <span class="t1 hoverable">society</span> was made by
a small <span class="t3 t17 t26 hoverable">number</span> of German workmen in London, who had
been expelled from France in 1839 for taking part in the riots
in Paris. Its members consisted of Germans, Hungarians,
Poles, Danes and Swedes. Of the few English members Ernest
Jones was one. The <span class="t1 hoverable">society</span> was on friendly terms with the
English Socialists, the Chartists, and the London French
Democratic

Society. Out of that friendship sprang the <span class="t1 hoverable">Society</span> of the
Fraternal Democrats, who were in correspondence with a
<span class="t3 t17 t26 hoverable">number</span> of democratic societies in Belgium. In November,
1847, a German Communist Conference was held in London,
at which Dr. Karl Marx (real name Morde-chai) was present.
In the manifesto then put forth it was declared that the aim of
the Communists was the overthrow of the rule of the
capitalists by the acquisition of political power. The practical
measures by which this was to be effected were the abolition
of private property in <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">land</span> ; the centralization of credit in the
<span class="t13 t23 hoverable">hands</span> of the <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">State</span> — the leading agitators of course to be the
chiefs of the <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">State</span> — by means of a national bank ; the
centralization of the means of transport in the <span class="t13 t23 hoverable">hands</span> of the
<span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">State</span> ; national workshops ; the reclamation and improvement
of <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">land</span> ; and the gratuitous education of all the children.
" In 1860, a Trade Unionist, Manhood Suffrage, and Vote
by Ballot Association was established, of which G. Odger, a
shoemaker, was chairman. As if it had not enough of what
might be <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> legitimate <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> to do, the association also
undertook to agitate in favour of Poland, for which purpose it
co-operated with the National League for the Independence of
Poland. The London International Exhibition of 1862 induced
the French government to assist many French workmen with
means to visit that exhibition... " and "... on the 5th August, all
the delegates met at a dinner given to them by their English
colleagues at Freemason's Hall, where an address was read
which formed, as it were, the foundation-stone of the International. The Imperial Commission that had enabled the
French workmen to visit the London Exhibition had no doubt
furnished them with return tickets. But several of the artisans
made no <span class="t4 t18 hoverable">use</span> of their <span class="t2 t3 t5 t10 t12 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">second</span>

The next year, another meeting was arranged and this was
followed by others. At last one was held in London on Sept.
24, 1864, presided over by Professor Beesly, at which it was
finally determined to establish a permanent organization of
the working <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> of the civilized world. The International
Working Men's Association was <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> founded. In The Jewish
Encyclopaedia, Article on Karl Marx, we read that Mazzini
and Marx were entrusted with the task of preparing the
address and the constitution. Then came the big public
meeting held on September 28, 1864 at St. Martin's Hall,
which " declared the International Working Men's
Association to be established and congresses were appointed
to be held at different times and places to decide on the
measures to be <span class="t7 t10 t12 t26 hoverable">taken</span> to found the working men's Eldorado.
Many societies at first were affiliated, but dissensions soon
broke out among them, and many, such as the Italian Working
Men's Society, withdrew again. " 3
This withdrawal of the Italian section was doubtless
influenced by its recognition of the subversion of the original
scheme for the amelioration of industrial conditions by the
Mazzinian revolutionary agents.
" At a meeting held in London, in 1865, the '
re-establishment of Poland entire and independent ' was again
one of the questions discussed. The Paris delegates were for
avoiding political questions; but Mr. Odger reminded them
that Poland had furnished the occasion for the establishment
of the association,

Another resolution favouring Polish Independence was

After such remarks, the International was evidently

They put the name of Temple on their cards and bills. Their

" On September 3rd 1870, the disaster of Sedan became
known at Paris. On the next day, Lyons, Marseilles, Toulouse,
and Paris proclaimed the Republic. This simultaneous
movement was the result of an understanding existing
between the leading members of the International in the
various parts of France ; but that the 'Jules Favres and
Gambettas, ' that vermine bourgeoise, as the International
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> them, should obtain any share of power, was very
galling to the demagogues. At Lyons and Marseilles, however,
the supreme <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> fell into the <span class="t13 t23 hoverable">hands</span> of the lowest wretches.
The Commune installed at Lyons began its <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> by raising
the red flag — that of the International. At Paris the
association pretended at first to be most anxious to fight the
Prussians. When the battalions were sent to the front, however,
it was found that those comprising most Internationals were
the most ready ' to fall back in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> order, ' or even to fly in

Thomas pointed out this instructive <span class="t24 hoverable">fact</span> to the readers of the
Journal Officiel. But when a few Prussian regiments entered

CHAPTER

LXXXVI

THE KU-KLUX KLAN
(Founded 1865)
The Ku-Klux Klan was the name of an American secret
association formed by the Whites of the Southern States for
self protection after the Civil war.
It was started at 1865 at Pulaski, Tennessee, as a club for
young men. The period of organization of the K. K. K. lasted
from 1865 to 1868. It absorbed other societies of similar aims
such as the Knights of the White Camelia, the White
Brotherhood, the White League, the Pale Faces, Black
Cavalry, White Rose, etc.
Apart from the protection of whites, one of its chief aims
was opposition to a government based on negro suffrage such
as the North wanted to impose on the South.
The Klan denominated the entire South as the Invisible
Empire under the rule of a Grand Wizard : General N. B.
Forrest. Each <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">state</span> was a Realm under a Grand Dragon; each
county a Province under a Grand Giant, etc.
The avowed principles were the maintenance of <span class="t13 hoverable">peace</span> and
order, of the laws of God, of the political and social
supremacy of the white race and also the prevention of the
intermingling of the races.
497

498

OCCULT THEOCRASY

It showed strenuous opposition to the " scallawags " and "
carpet-baggers " as they <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> the Northern Whites who
incited the negroes to commit all kinds of depredations
against the Whites of the South.
In 1871 and 1872, the United States Congress enacted a
series of " Force Laws " to break the K. K. K. By that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span>
however the negro was once more subdued and the K. K. K.'s
central organization was disbanded.
Its <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> however survived and reasserted itself in 1915
when it was revived.
For development of this organization see <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">Chapter</span> CXXIII.

LXXXVII

SOCIETAS ROSICRUCIANA IN ANGLIA
(Founded 1866)
For an historical sketch of the Societas Rosicruciana in
Anglia, the cover name for modern Illuminism, we can do no
better than turn to such an authority as its historian William
Wynn Westcott, erstwhile Supreme Magus of the Society.
The following items of information are gleaned from his
History of the Societas Rosicruciana in Anglia, published in
1910. 1 The official statement of the aims of the <span class="t1 hoverable">Society</span> reads
as follows :— " The aim of the <span class="t1 hoverable">Society</span> is to afford mutual aid
and encouragement in working out the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> problems of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Life</span>
and in searching out the secrets of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Nature</span> ; to facilitate the
study of the system of philosophy founded <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the Cabala
and the doctrines of Hermes Trismegistus, which was
inculcated by the original Fratres Rosae-Crucis of Germany,
A. D. 1450 ; and to investigate the <span class="t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t18 t19 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">meaning</span> and symbolism of
all that now remains of the wisdom, <span class="t2 t6 t8 t9 t10 t15 t18 t19 t21 t22 t23 t24 t28 t29 hoverable">art</span> and literature of the
ancient world. "
1. Dr. Wynn Westcott, M. W. Supreme Magus, History of The Societas
Rosicruciana in Anglia, IX, privately printed, Dec. 30, 1900. Copyright.
British Museum Press Mark 0475 h54.

" The Societas Rosicruciana in Anglia was founded in 1866
by Frater Robert Wentworth Little, an eminent Freemason
with much literary talent, and of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> personal popularity. He
was Secretary of the Province of Middlesex, and Secretary of
the Royal Masonic Institution for Girls. He became the first
Supreme Magus and <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t12 t17 t19 t20 t27 t29 hoverable">Master</span> General of the College in 1867.
His <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> and authority emanated from <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> sources, and
were supplemented by the learning and researches of several
other prominent students of occult philosophy. Brother
William Henry White, the Grand Secretary of England,
preserved certain Rosi-crucian papers2 which had ccme into
his possession on attaining office in 1810, at Freemason's Hall,
and ot these he made no <span class="t4 t18 hoverable">use</span> ; Brother Little fouud these
papers and <span class="t4 hoverable">used</span> them. At the same time, and with the <span class="t2 hoverable">object</span>
of re-constituting a Rosicrucian College in London, he
availed himself of certain <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> and authority which
belonged to Brother Kenneth R. H. Mackenzie, who had,
during a stay in Germany in earlier life, been in
communication with German Adepts who claimed a descent
from previous generations of Rosi-crucians. German Adepts
had admitted him to some grades of their system, and had
permitted him to attempt the formation of a group of Masonic
students in England, who under the Rosicrucian name might
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">form</span> a partly esoteric society. With this license and with the
manuscripts of ritual information, which Brother White had
discovered in the vaults of Freemason's Hall, Fratres R. W.
Hughan, Woodman, O'Neal Haye, Irwin and some others, the
present English rituals were adopted, and have been in <span class="t4 t18 hoverable">use</span>

I. — That the meetings of the <span class="t1 hoverable">Society</span> shall be held in
London at such <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">house</span> as the majority of the members shall

shall select. The first meeting in the year shall be considered
as the obligatory meeting and any member unable to attend on
that occasion or at the banquet meeting shall be required to
send a <span class="t0 t11 t24 hoverable">written</span> excuse to the Secretary-General. Each brother
present at the banquet shall pay his quota towards the
expenses thereof.
III. — The Master-general and the Officers shall be
elected annually at the obligatory meeting and shall be
induced into their several offices on the same evening. The
Master-general shall then appoint the Assistant officers for
the year.
IV. — No brother shall be eligible for election to the
office of Master-general or Deputy Master-general unless he
shall have served one year as an Ancient, and have attained
the <span class="t7 hoverable">third</span> Order; and no brother shall be eligible for the offices
of Treasurer-general, Secretary-general, or Ancient, unless he
be a member of the <span class="t2 t3 t5 t10 t12 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">second</span> Order.

research to which the <span class="t1 hoverable">society</span> restricts itself — mystic and

We however submit the following suggestions as a logical
deduction from a close study of the organization, activities
and connections of the Societas Rosicruciana in Anglia.
English Grand. Lodge is today what it was intended to be at
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> of its creation, by disciples of avowed
Rosicrucianism, namely a dragnet or nursery. Under the guise
of philanthropy, humanitarianism, democratic ideals, and the

The sifting takes <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> from the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> of
